DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF THE HONOURABLE DAME ENID MURIEL LYONS, A.D., G.B.E.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, it is with particular regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 2 September of the Honourable Dame Enid Muriel Lyons, a former member of the House of Representatives for the division of Darwin, former Vice-President of the Executive Council and widow of a former Prime Minister, the Right Honourable J. A. Lyons. I wish to make a few remarks. I was privileged, as many of us were, to know Dame Enid Lyons-on my part for some 35 years, indeed, the whole of the post-war years. She was a remarkable woman and a remarkable Australian as you, Mr President, would acknowledge. Not only was she the distinguished wife of a distinguished Prime Minister but also in her own way, in her own talents, in her own qualities, she achieved a quality of excellence that was acknowledged. She was a devoted wife and mother. She was a mother of some 11 children-a large family. She was a schoolteacher, I think, married to a schoolteacher. She entered Parliament and became a Minister and Vice-President of the Executive Council. I think she was the first woman member of the House of Representatives and the first woman member of Federal Cabinet-positions of great distinction. She was created a Dame of the Order of Australia in the Australia Day Honours List in 1980 for her public and parliamentary service.

SPEECH.PARA: I think all who knew her would say that the outstanding thing was the quality of the woman herself. She had a warmth of charm and affection that all who associated with her knew and were the better for. She transmitted a love and affection that made her a very distinctive person. Amongst her acquaintances and friends she was talented and an articulate speaker. She was a very distinctive writer and author, and all in all one of our great Australians. She lived a full life. I think she was in the fullness of some 84 years of her life when she died. Therefore, whilst regretting her passing one acknowledges the great contribution she made to this country. I move:

That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on 2 September of the Honourable Dame Enid Muriel Lyons, a member of the House of Representatives for the division of Darwin from 1943 to 1951, Vice-President of the Executive Council from 1949 to 1951, and widow of the former Prime Minister the Right Honourable J. A. Lyons, places on record its appreciation of her long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to her family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Carrick. I would like to associate the Opposition with the remarks that the honourable senator has made about the late Dame Enid Lyons. I believe that it is true to say that her many qualities and talents have been amply described in the obituaries and other tributes that have appeared in the Press and elsewhere. Perhaps I could just dwell on one or two points. Firstly, there is no doubt, from her record, that she was a highly talented person in her own right. I did not have the advantage of knowing her, as did Senator Carrick.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, the fact that she was the first woman member of the House of Representatives and the first woman member of a Federal Cabinet is of historic importance. Nowadays as we look around this Senate and, since the last election, when we look in one section of the House of Representatives, we see that she was a pioneering figure in that sense. It is to be hoped that the example of her success will be emulated by many women members of the House of Representatives and the Senate, that the rapidity with which women are newly elected to membership of both chambers will increase and that in that process the pioneering example of Dame Enid Lyons will be remembered. I have pleasure in commending the motion moved by Senator Carrick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator MASON
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support the motion and add their condolences to the family of the late Dame Enid Lyons. We note especially the significance of her career as the first woman member of the House of Representatives and, indeed, as the first woman Minister in this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I met Dame Enid Lyons when she was a commissioner of the Australian Broadcasting Commission from 1951 to 1962. Effectively, as some honourable senators will remember, that could be called the Boyer era, during which the ABC expanded significantly its operations outside this country. As a small part of that process, I was able to observe the enormous impact of that move by the ABC upon our neighbours in Asia. It had a large and permanent influence on our relationships with a number of South East Asian countries, not the least Indonesia, Malaysia in its formative stages, and Singapore. Perhaps most important of all, that influence was a grass roots influence. The situation arose that the largest audience of the Australian Broadcasting Commission was in Indonesia. I believe that that still remains the situation.

I know from my own experience that, as a commissioner, Dame Enid Lyons was an active supporter of that wider role for the ABC. I take the opportunity to draw attention to that later, but by no means least, part of her career.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate myself and my Party, the National Country Party, with this motion of sympathy for the family and friends of the late Dame Enid Lyons, who was the first woman member of the House of Representatives, which she served in a distinguished way over a period of some 8 years. She was a fine speaker and a well-known and loved family woman. Indeed, she contributed a great deal to this Parliament and provided an example which is being followed more and more as the years go by. I merely reiterate and commend the remarks of previous speakers to this motion of condolence and extend the sympathy of my own party also to the relatives and friends of the late Dame Enid Lyons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to associate myself with the condolences that have been expressed by the other speakers to this motion. Not only was Dame Enid Lyons a mother and stateswoman but also she was a talented and very readable author. Her books, including her collected newspaper columns, give immense enjoyment to people of a variety of ages and tastes, particularly those who are ill. I speak personally and with gratitude of the enjoyment that her books gave to one person.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the things about Dame Enid Lyons was that she was a lady-a lady of compassion and humour. One of the most moving tributes was to see yesterday the people of Devonport, in their thousands, lining the streets while the cortege proceeded to the cemetery. I should like to associate myself with the remarks that have preceded mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to be associated with the motion of condolence. I simply wish to speak of Dame Enid as a lady of great charm whom I really met only once though of course there were many brief encounters in the course of those community affairs with which she was associated right up until her death. But that one real occasion of meeting was a favoured one because it was in her own home. When I first arrived in Devonport in July 1978 as a fledgling senator, Dame Enid invited me to dinner in the company of her grandson, Peter Lyons. I remember going with some trepidation, knowing her reputation as a lady of great physical and spiritual toughness, but I need not have feared. Her hospitality was indeed very gracious; her reminiscing was fascinating. It was not reminiscing which dwelt in the past; it simply took pleasure in the past. She was indeed very alive to the present and it is this quality of being truly alive, vivacious in the real sense of the word, that I think remains with me as one reflects on Dame Enid's life. Her language sparkled in the same way as her eyes and indeed her whole manner.

SPEECH.PARA: For those of my generation and younger who did not know Dame Enid in her political heyday that sort of memory of the heart I think is in some complementary way a tribute alongside the great public tributes which properly are paid to her public life. It is a privilege to be associated with this condolence motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is difficult to pay an adequate tribute to a great person, and Dame Enid Lyons was certainly a great person. I first met Dame Enid Lyons in the mid-1940s. Over a period I met every member of her family in a very wide variety of contexts. My impressions of her life are probably different from other people's but to me it was all the more remarkable because it was so largely two separate lives, one after the other and each one being so much more than normal people would ever expect to have. During the 1920s and 1930s Dame Enid Lyons played a very strong part in providing the stability and backing for her husband's political achievements, in both the State and Federal spheres, which culminated with his election as Prime Minister. All the while there was the family, and a very large family at that. It was expected that following her husband's sudden death Dame Enid would have slipped from the limelight to become simply the widow of a former Prime Minister. It was as holder of the seat of Darwin that Dame Enid blossomed into what I would call her second state and with the benefit of 30 years of ingrained politics she immediately demonstrated the prowess that she had.

SPEECH.PARA: Dame Enid was a great and true feminist. There was never a time, however, that she bragged about being a woman, nor did she apologise for it. She was the full person in every respect. In her first speech in Federal Parliament she said that any woman entering the public arena must justify herself not as a woman but as a person. The state of her health produced her retirement from Parliament at a relatively young age which enabled her to carry on her most influential community achievements for a further 30 years. I think I will always remember her for three major items: Firstly, her christian beliefs and practices that were the great motivation of her life; secondly, that warmth and openness that visitors always received at the front door of 'Home Hill'; and, thirdly, the magnificence of her oratory and the use of the language.

I will always remember two of her addresses as the best addresses I have ever heard. One was delivered at a Tasmanian Rostrum club meeting. The Honourable Les Bury had accepted an invitation to attend the meeting and at 4.30 he sent a telegram to say he was unable to attend. The meeting was in Devonport. A quick conference determined that an approach should be made to Dame Enid. When I arrived at her home she had finished her evening meal and was preparing for an early night. Within an hour she was at the conference and she delivered absolutely the most perfect 40-minute address I have ever heard, one that any other speaker would have required days and days to put together.

The second occasion was the last time when I heard her deliver an address and it occurred about two years ago. It also was magnificent. After it was over she said to me: 'I think that will be my last speech. You know, I can't remember things now and for the first time in my life I have had to carry with me a piece of paper with notes on it in case I forget'. Needless to say, she did not forget and she did not use the piece of paper. She had an enormously keen wit, a wit that was not flippant, a very deep and meaningful wit. She was a great woman and a great person. History may record her as the greatest Tasmanian woman, or possibly even the greatest Tasmanian. Whatever status she is given, it will not matter; Australia should be thankful for the life and contribution of this very great person.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in the motion of condolence to the many relatives of Dame Enid Lyons. I think each of the qualities that have been expressed here today-every quality that Dame Enid had-is a quality that every woman would aspire towards. She was a loving wife and a loving mother. She was gentle and oh so very feminine. She was caring not only for her family but for all those around her. She was of tremendous support to her husband during his difficult days-and there were many difficult days. She was of great support to him throughout his period as Prime Minister. As has been said by many honourable senators, she was a wonderful speaker. She could reduce her audience to tears, be they men or women, and indeed she did so on many occasions. Anyone who reads her books will know only too well that she was quite capable of speaking in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Three weeks before her death, she played the organ in the church in which she was buried. This was her custom. Indeed, about two months ago she and I were guests at an annual dinner of the Soroptomists Club in Devonport. As usual, she was very charming, very vivacious, and she was surrounded by people. The fact that she told me on that evening that she had willed the house, in the memory of her husband, to the people of Devonport really described how much she loved her city in Tasmania. It is with sincere sympathy that I offer my condolences to her very large family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with the motion of condolence and to pay tribute to the remarkable life of the late Dame Enid Lyons. In doing so, I acknowledge the great contribution made by this very great Tasmanian and I pass on my sincere sympathy to her family. I wish also to place on the Senate record a tribute paid by a former Tasmanian senator in this place, Sir Reginald Wright. The tribute reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Courage, intelligence and character are the thoughts that her life means to us. Affection and love so natural in her were shared not only by her family but by her friends throughout the nation.
She had a marvellous faculty of imparting persuasion to the soul by speech and by example. She was truly a great national leader.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 244 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

1. That the decision by the Federal Government to introduce fees at the Repatriation General Hospital, Greenslopes, was made without prior consultation with medical staff at that hospital and implemented at short notice.
2. That fee introduction will place the hospital in the untenable position of having to compete with the State's free hospital system.

3. That this competition will result in a substantial loss of specialist medical personnel and community non-entitled patients, both of whom are complementary and vital to maintaining the standards of excellence that this hospital has achieved.

Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, call upon the Government through the Minister for Veterans Affairs to declare a moratorium on the introduction of fees at the Repatriation General Hospital, Greenslopes, until the full ramifications of this decision are studied more closely and the patients and staff are allowed adequate time to prepare for any financial changes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:
That since 1788 discrimination has existed in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of sex, race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy and/or sexual preference;

That since 1788 such discrimination has been accepted and promoted by Australian laws and practices, particularly in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs, in promotion to positions of authority and lucrative incomes, in the provision of goods and services, in the provision of accommodation and generally in relation to political, economic and social institutions of power.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That adequate and appropriate laws be immediately formulated and passed through the Parliament to render unlawful discrimination in all areas over which the Commonwealth holds power, namely, in employment of all persons in the Commonwealth Public Service and employed in Commonwealth Statutory Authorities and other bodies, in the provision of accommodation and the provision of goods and services under Commonwealth jurisdiction and also in all areas over which legislation for the Australian Capital Territory would be valid.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioner Benefits
PETITION.PARA: To the President and Members of the Senate assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth:

That your petitioners are gravely concerned that the Government is not fulfilling its responsibility in ensuring an adequate standard of living for all Australians, which is causing untold hardship on relief agencies' limited resources, and require the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:
1. That the Commonwealth Government raise the level of all pensions and benefits at least to the poverty line.
2. That the Commonwealth Government reconsider its recent decisions in relation to the health system and cuts to Commonwealth activity.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert further poverty and suffering in our community by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discrimination Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individuals-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Women's Centres
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That many thousands of women in the Australian community who use the services of women's refuges, women's health centres, and women's rape crisis centres:

(1) Express their concern at the decision of the Federal Government to pass to the States the responsibility of funding those essential services because of the poor record already demonstrated by some states;
(2) Call on the Federal Government to reverse that decision;
(3) Request that the Government ensure one department to administer all funds for the above under the heading of Women's Services;
(4) Propose that future funding should be on a guaranteed triennial basis, taking into account inflation and indexation increases; and
(5) Ask for a positive policy commitment for a substantial injection of funds to consolidate existing services, and to develop new initiatives for women and children in the Australian community.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Immigration Policy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens showeth:

That we protest at the breakdown of our restrictive immigration policy which many members of this parliament vigorously supported in their promises to the Australian people, but who are now opposing the will of the people as has been expressed in numerous public opinion polls on the subject of maintaining a homogenous European society.
That we are concerned at the growing number of inter-racial disturbances, many of which appear to go unreported.

That we fear that we are repeating the mistake of Britain and urge the Government to seek the wishes of the people in determining the advisability of returning to our pre-1966 restrictive immigration policy.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications whether his attention has been drawn to statements by the former General Manager of the Overseas Telecommunications Commission, Mr Harold White, that telephone subscribers are being forced to pay more because the Government refuses to fulfil its function as the sole shareholder of Telecom Australia. Mr White alleged that these extra telephone charges were due in large measure to the Government's tight restrictions on borrowings by Telecom. In addition to those aspects of the question, will the Minister confirm that the report by the McKinsey organisation in relation to Telecom's borrowing capacity has been in the hands of the Government for well over a year? Is it not a fact that that report has been suppressed by the Government because it criticises the way in which the Government has exercised unfair controls over Telecom's borrowing capacity?

—I am able to say that a long period has elapsed since the last time telephone charges were increased. I hope that the honourable senator acknowledges that the Government has done all within its power to keep telephone charges down. I have no particular knowledge of whether Mr Harold White-I think that is the person to whom the honourable senator referred-made the statements attributed to him. I would want to see the entire statement and I will undertake to try to get it. In the same way, I will try to get details of the statement of the McKinsey organisation, to which Senator Button referred, to see whether what he has stated is correct. I repeat that it is the desire of the Government to provide a first rate telecommunication system at the cheapest cost possible to subscribers in Australia.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DIABETES: USE OF FOETUSES IN POSSIBLE CURE

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Health whether he has seen the report in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald headed 'Scientists set to use foetus bank'. The report indicated that aborted foetuses are expected to be used in a tissue bank to be set up within six months in Canberra to provide pancreatic tissue for a possible diabetes cure. Does the Minister realise what serious implications this report, if true, has for many of us in this chamber who reject the killing of unwanted babies? Will he, firstly, ascertain whether the report is correct? Secondly, will he inform the Senate how much Government funding has already been given and how much will be given to this project, and from which particular Budget appropriation? Thirdly, will he inform the Senate of the source of the so-called aborted foetuses to be used in the project and more importantly of the ages these little babies must be before being suitable for the project? Fourthly, will he inform the Senate whether these little babies must be born alive to be of use to the project? Fifthly, will he inform the Senate whether the Woden Valley Hospital will be used as a bank for this tissue? Finally, will he inform the Senate that the Government will not permit its medical facilities to be used for such purposes?

—I did not see the article in yesterday's Sydney Morning Herald. That is the answer to the first part of the honourable senator's question. I am therefore unable to answer the very detailed questions which he puts to me under about seven or eight headings. I will seek to get that information for him. I am aware of the great interest by medical science today in the use of transplanted tissue, such as pancreatic tissue, as a possible cure for illnesses such as diabetes. I am sure that the honourable senator, who expresses his concern over the matter of abortion, would join with me in expressing the hope that, properly used, tissue transplants can lead to some medical advances. I simply remind the honourable senator that not all aborted foetuses would be the result of induced abortions-that there are unfortunately too many spontaneous abortions. But that does not alter the fact that I will seek the answers to his questions, including the questions relating to funding and those relating to the Woden Valley Hospital and whether it is playing any part in the matters referred to in the newspaper story.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. It concerns Aspect House, an organisation providing respite care for the families of handicapped children in Hobart which was funded from the Minister's appropriations as a pilot study. Has the program conducted at Aspect House been evaluated? What was the result of such evaluation? Is it intended to continue funding Aspect House? Is it general policy that if programs which are funded as pilot programs are successful funding will continue?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aspect House some time ago received approval for a pilot project under the family support scheme. That approval, I think, applied until a couple of years ago. The project actually got under way relatively recently; I think within the last four or five months. I speak from memory when I say that the original approval was given for funds to the order of $60,000 for a full year. However, the scheme as subsequently got under way was rather more financially ambitious than that. My advice from the State Minister concerned, Mr Lohrey, is that the full amount of the original funds and, indeed, the additional funds were expended within the first four or five months of operation. This matter came as a surprise to Mr Lohrey as it did to me. In any event, Mr Lohrey and I have been in fairly frequent communication over the last week about this project. It was my anticipation that a joint Press release would be issued in Tasmania today by us, but I am not sure whether that release has been issued.

ANSWER.PARA: I do not wish to pre-empt Mr Lohrey in this matter, but I can say to the Senate that the Commonwealth and the State are jointly undertaking an examination of this project rather earlier than an evaluation would normally proceed, namely, after a relatively few months of operation. The future funding of that scheme will depend upon the evaluation which has been made. A problem concerned the organisers of Aspect House in that they had received some $15,000 more than the funding approval. However, that matter has been regularised by the joint action of Mr Lohrey and me. We hope that the evaluation can proceed over the period for which funding remains and that a sensible decision can be made subsequently. The problem is always there when governments fund organisations. I have had experience of that in the portfolios of Aboriginal Affairs and Social Security. This is a frequent experience for my friend and colleague, Senator Peter Baume. When funds are made available and there is fairly substantial overspending there are real problems in dealing with the matter within the allowances made in a Budget. Mr Lohrey and I share the problem, and in a spirit of amity, comity and good will we are trying to sort it out.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Having in mind that the Australian community is constantly being urged to invest in Australia in order to keep ownership of our resources in Australian hands, does the Minister agree that the current system of taxing dividends on Australian investments would act as a deterrent rather than an incentive to such a concept? Further, can the Minister explain why those who invest their own savings in risk taking should be the only ones who have their rewards subjected to two payments of income tax?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Treasurer and the Government are very interested in the role played by the small investor in this country in the development of Australia's resources and assets. I think it will be recalled that the Treasurer in his recent Budget Speech made reference to the matter of small investors and the fact that the Government was examining the present income tax treatment of dividends of people with modest shareholdings. It is also a fact that the Campbell Committee of Inquiry into the Australian Financial System is expected to report shortly and it is thought that some comment will be made on matters such as this. The Treasurer and the Government decided not to make any decisions in this Budget which related to dividends on small shareholdings. As I say, the Treasurer did make reference to it and it is a matter that is under consideration by the Government. When the report of the Campbell Committee is being dealt with, this could well be a matter that would, at least, be given active consideration by the Government.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer, concerns the proposed sales tax on books, newspapers and magazines which is to apply from 1 January next year. Is the Minister aware that, in imposing this tax, the Government will be breaking a long-standing tradition of the free and democratic nations and indeed inviting comparison of our country with the totalitarian states? What guarantees can the Government offer that the principle of imposing such a tax would not permit some future government to increase it to the extent of exercising an undue and unfair influence on the print media? While I am aware that Australia is not a signatory to the Florence Agreement, we have expressed support for it many times. How does the Minister reconcile that support with this proposed tax measure?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have figures with me which would show which countries may impose a tax on periodicals, newspapers or books. I could refer to the fact that in many countries a value added tax is imposed on many commodities which, I assume, would include those mentioned. As to breaking a long-standing tradition, it is a fact that in this Budget a tax is imposed on a number of items that had previously not been subjected to tax. As to giving any guarantees about any future government and any action it might take to increase taxes of any kind, I think it would be understood that any future government would make its own decisions on the broad range of income-producing Bills that it would wish to introduce. The fact that this Government has introduced a tax on one measure or another would in no way pre-empt what a future government may decide to do. I do not see great relevance in looking at what guarantees we could give with regard to any future government on any matter where a future government may choose to impose taxes as it sees fit. As far as sales tax in this Budget is concerned, these matters will be discussed shortly in the Senate and, if there are any points that the Treasurer wishes to make, I will see that they are made at that time.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer her to Table 1 of the Commonwealth Government Budget outlays by economic type contained in the recent Budget Papers. Is it a fact that Commonwealth outlays for its own purposes, excluding defence and payments to the States, have grown 59 per cent between 1977-78 and 1981-82, and that payments to the States during the same period will have grown only 33 per cent? Is it also a fact that the payments to the States in 1981-82 are limited to an increase of 9 per cent whereas the Commonwealth outlays this year for its own purposes have been set at 15 per cent? Does it not follow, therefore, that the States are being asked to accept a lesser growth rate out of Commonwealth expenditure than the Commonwealth is prepared to impose upon itself?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think that the facts as stated are broadly correct, although perhaps I ought to say that the increase in funds for payments to the States this year is estimated to be 8 per cent and not 9 per cent as mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne. The comparisons perhaps depend very much on the period chosen and the terms that we would include when making those comparisons. I think we ought to acknowledge that there was a very generous growth of payments to the States between 1972 and 1975. It ought also to be said that the economic strategy followed by the Government in the 1981-82 Budget required measures to cut back the relative size of the public sector to make room for the expansion and the needs of the private sector in this country. The room for expenditure restraint varied between different functional areas of the Budget. About 30 per cent of the Budget relates to social security and welfare matters and it is very difficult to achieve savings or cutbacks which were not achieved in this area. Health grants to the States and so on had a different application in this year. I suppose that one could make comparisons between Commonwealth Government expenditure on its own account and expenditure for the States. However, I simply say that the strategy in this Budget was to cut back expenditure in the public sector and wherever this was possible without serious disruption to programs it was done in the way in which the Budget Papers show. I have no further explanation to offer with regard to the changes in the comparisons between the Commonwealth and the States except to say that if the States wish to increase their own expenditure on their own account their revenue raising would be in their own hands.

—I address my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Now that the Liberal Government has sold off huge slices of our natural resources to foreign investors, is it hell-bent on selling off the land itself? When will the Government change the guidelines of the Foreign Investment Review Board to control the amount of land that can be sold to overseas individuals and companies, especially where land agents can circumvent the present value of $350,000 by subdividing farmland and selling it off in smaller blocks? Will the Government consider holding a referendum to get the constitutional power to control the ownership of Australian land and resources?

—The last part of Senator Elstob's question really provides the essential answer to the remainder of his question. The fact of the matter is that sovereignty over land in the six States rests with each of the State governments, so that the determination of whether a purchase of land is made by an Australian citizen or a foreigner is a matter entirely and essentially for the State government concerned. That is quite clear. As to the initial rhetoric, the fact is that it was this Government which set up the Foreign Investment Review Board and it was this Government which established that there should be at least 50 per cent Australian equity in these resources areas. We have insisted on that. It is extremely difficult to trace money that comes into this country because it can pass through a primary purpose into a secondary or tertiary purpose and fulfil its primary responsibilities on the way. Therefore, basically the matter must rest essentially with the States. The State governments are responsible governments duly elected by the people. They have always had land as their responsibility. My Government sees no reason at all why there should be a referendum to change the status or the sovereignty of the State governments on this matter.

—I direct my question to the Attorney-General. Has the Commonwealth Government taken account of the increasing support for four-year parliaments, not only in this Parliament as expressed by all parties but also in State parliaments and increasingly in the community at large? What specific considerations will be given by the Cabinet to this important proposal? Has the Attorney-General himself completed the preparation of the case for four-year parliaments and the arrangements that would be necessary for the holding of a referendum? Finally, will the committee of the Australian Constitutional Convention examining this matter soon be reconvened?

—The Government is, of course, particularly aware of the discussion that has been taking place in the community and amongst political leaders about four-year parliaments. It is naturally interested in such an important question. In fact, I have instructed my Department to prepare a paper on the whole matter for consideration by Cabinet at an early date. When we talk about four-year parliaments, we have to take into consideration the question of whether we simply have an upper limit of four years in the life of a parliament as we have an upper limit of three years, or whether we have fixed four-year parliaments. Of course, quite a lot of literature has been generated on the subject. As I said, Cabinet will be considering my paper when it is presented, I trust in the near future. In regard to that part of the question dealing with the Australian Constitutional Convention Committee D which has a number of matters referred to it by the last sitting of the Constitutional Convention, I have taken some steps to try to fix a date in the near future for a meeting of that Committee. I have not yet had advice as to whether the proposed dates have been confirmed. I trust there will be a meeting shortly.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: SHIRE OF MOUNT MARSHALL: NATIONAL TELEVISION TRANSMITTER

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Communications tell me when this Government will proceed on a promise of the previous Minister for Post and Telecommunications, the Honourable A. A. Staley, that a national television transmitter will be built in the shire of Mount Marshall during 1981 which will bring television reception to 12 or 13 shires and a large number of country towns in this region? Can the Minister give a firm undertaking that this national television transmitter will proceed without any further delay?

—It may not surprise the honourable senator to know that I cannot give him immediate information on the question of a television transmitter at Mount Marshall. I am pleased to know that such a facility would bring viewing to 12 or 13 shires. I imagine I can get the information the honourable senator wants. At the same time I also would like to get the prospects for that same area from the installation of any satellite system in terms of an alternative method of television reception.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs. In view of the large increase in bankruptcy will the Minister give consideration to placing a time limit in which creditors must lodge notification of proof of debt? Further, is the Minister aware that at present there is no time limit and all too frequently creditors lodge proof of debt after the Receiver in Bankruptcy has notified in the Press his intention to declare a dividend? Would not the Minister acknowledge that considerable time would be saved in the office of the Receiver in Bankruptcy and that creditors would be paid more expeditiously if a time limit of say six months were required in which creditors would have to lodge their claim?

—I think it is well known that through the increase in the number of bankruptcies there has been a significant problem within the bankruptcy administration in the last year or so as to the details of clearing bankruptcy administrations through that office. In relation to the particular point which Senator Watson raised in regard to lodgment of proof of debts, I have no information. It seems that in the circumstances he outlined it could possibly occur. I need to refer the matter to the Minister and obtain a reply for him as to whether his solution would in fact answer the problem he has in mind.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the Gallery of the delegation from the Nigerian Parliament comprising the Senate Committee on Public Works. The delegation is led by the Chairman of the Committee, Senator Awyanwu. On behalf of honourable senators I extend to the delegation our best wishes and a very warm welcome to Australia.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is he aware that there are now six electorates out of nineteen in Queensland in which the enrolment tolerance exceeds the 10 per cent requirement and that enrolment in the largest electorate in that State now exceeds that of the smallest by some 42 per cent? Is he aware that similarly there are now five electorates in New South Wales, three in Victoria and two in Western Australia outside the 10 per cent tolerance range and that in the mainland States the largest electorate now exceeds the smallest by 43.5 per cent? What is the Government's intention concerning these anomalies? Does it contemplate a redistribution in order to rectify the many distortions in many electorates?

—I am aware as all honourable senators are of the requirements of the Commonwealth Electoral Act in relation to disparities between States and the differences in the size of electorates. I understand that my colleague the Minister for Administrative Services is also aware not only of the requirements of the Act but also of the figures to which the honourable senator refers. I believe he is already considering these matters and that he will make a statement at an appropriate time as to the action which he proposes to take.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I preface my question, which is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, in his capacity as Minister representing the Prime Minister, by referring him to Press reports concerning the Federal Government's attitude to a visit to South Africa earlier this year by a trade mission from the Perth Chamber of Commerce. Included in these reports was a statement by a spokesman for the Department of Foreign Affairs that:

QUESTION.PARA: The Australian Government's policy is that trade links can continue with South Africa, but that there should be no avoidable official assistance to such links.

Does the Minister agree that the expansion of overseas trade by Australian companies trading with South Africa continues to attract benefits from the operation of the Australian Government's export expansion grants and export marketing development grants? If so, will the Government, in accordance with its expressed views on South Africa and its apartheid policy, take action to exclude exports to South Africa from these schemes so that no official assistance and consequent encouragement is given to trade with South Africa?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not aware of the visit of representatives of the Perth Chamber of Commerce to South Africa but I understand that the existing export incentives legislation does not discriminate between markets. Export incentive grants are paid on the basis of the claimant's total global exports or marketing efforts, not on the basis of specific markets. In keeping with this principle, the Australian Government has not intended to vary the cover of the present schemes. However, this should not be seen as in any way being a weakening of the Australian Government's total opposition to apartheid, which has on many occasions been made known to the South African Government in the clearest terms.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINALS LAND RIGHTS: WRECK BAY COMMUNITY

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs: If the Government was prepared to legislate for Aboriginal land rights in the Northern Territory why has it not been prepared to legislate for land for Aboriginals in the Australian Capital Territory? I refer to the Wreck Bay community in the Territory which, after many years of negotiation with the Federal Government, appears to be no closer to obtaining the land rights that it is seeking. What is the current state of negotiations between the Government and the Aboriginal people of Wreck Bay and when will the Government take action on that community's claim for land rights?
—As the honourable senator might know, the situation in Wreck Bay has been under negotiation for some time.
—Too long.

—The honourable senator says 'too long'. The negotiations have been continuing. I will bring before the Senate an up-to-date account of those negotiations. I am confident that we can achieve a satisfactory solution to them and arrive at an appropriate arrangement for the people of Wreck Bay. I will bring a detailed statement on the matter before the Senate at an early date.

—Can the Minister for National Development and Energy tell the Senate what progress has been made in attempts to establish in Australia plantations of the jojoba bean, the oil from which is sometimes described as nature's miracle oil? As research scientists are continually finding further potential uses for the plant's wax, does the Minister believe that it has a future as an oil substitute in this country? Finally, is the Government encouraging or supporting the development of the industry?

—The particular vegetation referred to, which is spelt as 'jojoba' and I understand is pronounced 'hohoba', has been the subject of study by this Government. In fact, the Government is supporting research on the jojoba bean through the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, which is undertaking, with State Departments of Agriculture, laboratory studies as well as field trials in all mainland States. I will certainly bring that part of the honourable senator's question to the attention of the Minister for Science and Technology. As to the use of the material as an oil substitute, my understanding is that the liquid wax from the bean has a promising future as a substitute for sperm whale oil in a wide range of specialised applications. My understanding is that there is already a strong demand for the wax from the wild plant in the United States of America for use in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries. In sulphurised form it may find application as a transmission oil but I expect for the moment it will be too costly for use as a lubricating oil. However, it is not, as I understand it, considered at the moment to be a potential alternative liquid fuel but rather a lubricant. Plantations are a matter for the Minister for Primary Industry. I will bring the question to his attention. My understanding is that a large number of cultivation trials are in progress in Australia but no plantations have reached commercial production.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has the Minister seen Press reports recently about the record rise in the business of Mercantile Mutual Life Insurance Co. Ltd in the last financial year and in particular the contribution to that business of single premium policies which jumped by 139 per cent or a value of around $19.2m in the last year? I ask: Why has the Government not yet done anything about the blatant tax avoidance schemes being promoted by companies like Mercantile Mutual and also, of course, Australian Eagle Insurance Co. Ltd with its one year Eagle bonds of the same kind, which schemes involve interest on fixed interest investments being disguised as reversionary bonuses on life insurance policies and as such being tax exempt? Has any progress at all been made since 27 November last year, now nine months ago, when Senator Durack advised me in this chamber that the matters I have raised again today were under active consideration by the Treasurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have not seen the report referred to by Senator Evans and I have not any information on the matter raised by him. I will refer the matter to the Treasurer and seek an early answer. As far as tax avoidance is concerned, the honourable senator will be aware of the other steps that have been taken by the Treasurer over the past years. I will refer the specific matter that the honourable senator has raised to the Treasurer for an up-to-date report.

—I ask a question of the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the above average rainfall over much of Australia this year and the consequent superabundance of grass cover now to be expected and which would appear to make this fire season one to be remembered, can the Minister say whether arrangements are in hand to acquire the services of a number of Neptune or other specialist water bombers as discussed at the end of last year's fire season? If no action is yet under way, will the Minister undertake an urgent initiative to acquire these vital services so that the effectiveness of water bombing techniques in Australia may be proven?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My recollection is that at this stage of the bushfire season last year Senator Archer expressed a practical view on the matter. Whilst the control of bushfires, including the acquisition of equipment to fight them, is a State responsibility the matter of water bombing has been considered by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth seeks to assist in a number of ways and it responded to discussions about water bombing last year by arranging to provide a Royal Australian Air Force Hercules-not a Neptune-on a shared cost basis to test what is called a modular air-borne fire fighting unit during this coming fire fighting season. This follows an approach by the Victorian Government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is proposed that the fire fighting unit be tested in the Hercules aircraft during the Victorian bushfire season. I understand this unit works by laying down a chemical firebreak, not just a water one in the path of advancing bushfires by a mixture of water and fire retardant chemicals. The personnel from the RAAF, the Forests Commission of Victoria and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation attended a training course in Idaho in May of this year. A great deal of work is being done on this matter. I have a fair deal of information on the matter arising out of last year's inquiries. I will be happy to give the information to the honourable senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and follows that asked by Senator Mason concerning Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A). Before the Minister took responsibility for the passage of those Bills through the Senate, was she aware that the Bills had been drafted in a form entirely different from any other form in which similar Bills have come before the Senate in the past 50 years; in other words, that on this sole occasion machinery provisions, along with provisions imposing taxation, had been included in the one Bill? What was the purpose of that unique step? Was it simply to enable legal advice to be given to certain honourable senators that the Bills were non-amendable, hoping that those honourable senators would accept that at its face value? If not, what other possible explanation could exist for departing from procedures firmly founded on section 55 of the Constitution, which have been used for the past 50 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sales tax Bills that are before the Parliament are Bills that relate to the Budget. It is true that they may be in a different form from that in which amendments have been moved on previous occasions. As to dealing with them and some of the comments that I have seen made publicly in that respect, I think it ought to be understood that the sales tax Bills are intrinsically Bills that relate to the present Budget. They are money Bills. They are part of the Budget that is before the Parliament at present. Anyone who tried to prove otherwise, I think, would be indulging in semantics. The Bills are part of the Budget; they are Budget Bills. They seek to raise the revenue of the Government that is required in the Budget. They are in the form that, on advice from the Attorney-General's Department, is appropriate.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. With respect, the Minister did not answer any of the questions that I asked her. I asked her: Was she aware before she took responsibility for the passage of the sales tax Bills through the Senate that they had been drafted in a form different from that of similar Bills which have been presented to the Senate since 1930-over the past 50 years-and what was the reason for the difference on this sole occasion, namely, to include in those measures machinery provisions along with provisions imposing taxation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — It is a fact that the Bills that are before the House impose taxation. They are not machinery measures; they impose taxation. As far as the first part of the question is concerned, I was aware that the Bills were in the form in which they were presented to the House. They are Bills which impose tax on commodities; they impose tax on some commodities that formerly have not been taxed and increase rates of tax on others. To try to describe them other than as Bills which impose tax seems to me to ignore the purpose of the Bills, that is, to raise sales tax for the present Budget.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs say whether certain members of the World Peace Council recently have been refused visas to enter Australia? If that has occurred, will the Minister indicate how many members of that delegation were refused entry visas and on what grounds they were refused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I understand that several visitors from other countries may have come to Australia recently for meetings organised by the Australian Peace Committee, the Australian affiliate of the World Peace Council. I am informed that Ms Elena Petushkova, a Soviet citizen who also intended to visit Australia at the invitation of the Australian Peace Committee, was not issued a visa. It is not known whether Ms Petushkova is a member of the World Peace Council. It was decided that a visit by Ms Petushkova would not be appropriate in the light of the Government's current policy on entry to Australia by Soviet citizens following the Soviet invasion of Afganistan.

—I direct to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs a question which is virtually a corollary to the question asked by Senator Hamer on the cessation of the Community Youth Support Scheme. I put it to the Minister that, if she were to read the last Press release by the Honourable Neil Brown, No. 98/81, she would see that its whole thrust is that all the casualties on the cessation of CYSS are to be counselled on alternative training. Are we to assume that the alternative training will apply to the whole of the 55,000 participants in CYSS programs? If the Minister cannot give that assurance, can she indicate what will happen to those boys and girls who are not otherwise involved? Will they just lie on the sidelines?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has decided in this Budget not to continue funding CYSS projects beyond 31 October of this year. It ought to be said that circumstances have changed since the Scheme was introduced in 1976. Many new programs have been initiated and the resources devoted to the young, especially the young unemployed, have been increased. This year it is expected that about 210,000 young people will be assisted by the Government's range of manpower and training programs. Nearly 90,000 young people will be assisted this year under the Special Youth Employment Training Program. There have been increased subsidies under that program to assist these young people unemployed for eight months or more in the last 12 months. An increase in the range and level of educational opportunities under the Commonwealth's School to Work Transition Program for young people has also been dealt with this year. A transition allowance will be available to ensure that young employed people do not lack the incentive to undertake technical and further education courses. Strengthening of the counselling services through the Commonwealth Employment Service and support under the Commonwealth Rebate for Apprentice Full-time Training Scheme for the training of 95,000 apprentices are other matters that ought to be borne in mind.

ANSWER.PARA: As I think was said by my colleague Senator Chaney earlier today, the position of the people who would not be able to be assisted under alternative programs will be the subject of a report to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs. His Department is reviewing the CYSS projects at the present time. Until we are aware of the outcome of that investigation, and on the understanding that we have made an arrangement to donate the assets held by the CYSS projects to approved local organisations and that other matters will be the subject of a report to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs, I am unable to say whether a large number of people will not be able to be assisted by a number of the programs I have mentioned and by other programs which exist. I think we should await the outcome of a further comment from the Minister after his Department has had an opportunity to conduct the interviews which he has already described.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to ask a supplementary question. In the light of what the Minister has said and in view of the fact that the Scheme is to be wound up on 31 October, is the Minister sure that the statistics that are being kept will provide an accurate figure or will we have, as I described in my original question, boys and girls falling between the two schools of training and pre-training?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer to the Minister as to what date he would expect the statistics to be available to him. I think it would be premature to discuss the matter further until such time as the statistics are received by him. We can then ascertain whether there is a problem as outlined by Senator Mulvihill and, if so, the magnitude of it. I will refer the matter to the Minister for Employment and Youth Affairs for further comment.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. In view of the prevailing high interest rates, will the Government examine the possibility of adding interest to taxation refunds at the same interest rate as the Taxation Office charges on overdue payments? In other words, if a refund is mailed out at the end of August, the taxpayer could expect to receive two months' interest added to that refund. Secondly, if the Taxation Office objects to an item which has been deducted by a taxpayer but which it eventually allows, will the Government consider adding interest to the refunded amount so that the taxpayer is treated in a fair way?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will need to refer this matter to the Treasurer for a comment from him as to whether the Government would be prepared to pay interest on rebates or on items that were previously disallowed. I am sure that a suggestion of this kind has been made previously and no doubt the Commissioner of Taxation and the government of the day responded to it. I will seek information from the Treasurer as to his response at this time on the suggestion of Senator Townley.

—I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to a question I asked of him on 20 August concerning the leaking of the 1980-81 Budget. In his reply he promised to ask the 'proper authorities' whether the Government would release the Australian Federal Police report on the matter. I now ask the Minister: Who are the proper authorities and has he consulted with them? If so, what was the response and will he now table the Federal Police report on the matter. In view of the fact that he may be consulting the proper authorities, will he also ask whether any report from the Federal Police to the Government in relation to investigations on malpractices in the Australian meat export industry could be tabled at the same time?

—As to the last part of the question, my colleague Senator Chaney will be making a statement on the meat industry in this place in the immediate future. That will provide information for Senator Button. As to the first matter, the proper authority is the Treasurer, as well as the Department of the Treasury. The purport of the question and the answer in the past was sent to the Treasury. I was not aware that a response had not come forward. I regret that. I will seek a response and let Senator Button know of it.

—I direct a question to the Leader of the Goverment in the Senate in his own right and as the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Over recent days I have received messages on behalf of one Eamonn O'Connor, a person who is engaged in a hunger strike in Sydney. This situation is now becoming most distressing to several honourable senators who are receiving similar messages. Has he or the Government received messages from O'Connor? Has there been any response by the Government to O'Connor's plea for some approach to be made to the Thatcher Government? If the Government has received such messages and has not responded, would it in mercy advise O'Connor that if he continues he will die in vain because the Government can do nothing for him?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I think Senator Georges raised this matter previously and I have a response on the matter from the Minister for Foreign Affairs. The Australian Government is concerned about current developments in Northern Ireland and the continuing suffering and violence there. However, it is the Government's view that the problems of Northern Ireland are matters for resolution between the British Government and the people of Northern Ireland. As the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives on 29 April this year, Australia would not advance the cause of peace and stability in Northern Ireland by seeking to intervene in its affairs. The Australian Government has given Mr O'Connor and his supporters an opportunity to present their case. On behalf of the Government, on 27 August the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Honourable Tony Street, saw Mr Michael Durkin, the President of the Irish National Association of Australia and Mr Neil O'Donnell, President of the H Block Committee, regarding Mr Eamonn O'Connor's hunger strike. Mr Street heard the concerns expressed by Messrs Durkin and O'Donnell and reiterated the Government's view. This attitude was also set out in a letter from the Acting Prime Minister to Mr O'Donnell, dated 25 August. I seek leave to have that letter incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Dear Mr O'Donnell
I refer to your telegram to the Prime Minister of 9 August and subsequent messages concerning the hunger strike in Sydney by Mr Eamonn O'Connor.
The Australian Government is concerned about current developments in Northern Ireland and the continuing suffering and violence there.

It is the Government's view, however, that the problems of Northern Ireland are a matter for resolution between the British Government and the people of Northern Ireland. As the Prime Minister said in the House of Representatives on 29 April 1981 Australia would not advance the cause of peace and stability in Northern Ireland by seeking to intervene in its affairs.

From a humanitarian viewpoint, I sincerely hope that Mr O'Connor, both for his own sake and for the sake of his family, can be persuaded to desist from the action he has undertaken. I also sincerely hope that anyone who can bring any influence at all to bear on Mr O'Connor will also seek to persuade him against continuing his hunger strike.
Yours sincerely J. D. Anthony
Mr Neil O'Donnell
President
Sydney H Block Committee
86/103 Victoria Street
Potts Point, NSW 2011

TALK.START.PARA: — Mr Street emphasised again the Government's hope that Mr O'Connor could be persuaded to give up his hunger strike. He expressed his strong view that the violence in Northern Ireland should not arise as a matter in the Australian community. From an humanitarian viewpoint, the Government sincerely hopes that Mr O'Connor, both for his own sake and for the sake of his family, can be persuaded to desist from the action he has undertaken. We also sincerely hope that anyone who can bring any influence at all to bear on Mr O'Connor will seek to persuade him against continuing his hunger strike. Honourable senators will also be aware that Cardinal Freeman and five assistant bishops have issued a statement which included a call on Mr O'Connor to desist from his hunger strike.

ANSWER.PARA: The problems of Northern Ireland are long standing, complex and most tragic. For the common good of the people there at this particularly difficult period, restraint needs to be shown by all parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Attorney-General aware of the current moves in Queensland to have a special appropriation of more than $30,000 granted by the State Government to cover the personal costs of the Queensland Premier, following a successful defamation action against him? Does the Government regard this as a legitimate precedent for the public funding of personal or private legal costs incurred by members of government? QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS: WRECK BAY COMMUNITY

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —During Question Time, Senator Ryan asked a question concerning the Wreck Bay community and I promised to get some information for her. If such Act applied to Wreck Bay, it is very likely that the Aboriginal Land Commissioner would not grant land to Aborigines on the basis of traditional ownership and association. Therefore, some other mechanism is necessary to meet their needs. Further, the land tenure system in the Australian Capital Territory is different, being a system of leasehold tenure.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that, I can advise the honourable senator that what I said to her during Question Time is correct. Negotiations have been going on over a long period and the Aborigines at Wreck Bay have been offered their land on conditions which are as close as can be obtained in the Australian Capital Territory, where there is no freehold, to what they would get if they were in the Northern Territory. They have been offered perpetual leases of the land. This is the highest land interest now granted in the Australian Capital Territory. They have been promised that they would have the same rights in relation to any proposed mineral exploration and development as they would have under the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act. They have also been offered all of the land which they sought. I understand that, although this offer has been available for 12 months, the community has not yet signified its intention regarding the offer. If the honourable senator can bring her good offices to bear to encourage the community to look further at the offer, I would be grateful.
