TALK.START.PARA: -Mr President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

—I rise today as a result of an article which appeared in the Sunday Press on 6 September in a double page spread at pages 4 and 5 under the heading 'Dads Kidnap Squad! Senator hits out' and next to which is a photograph of myself-not a particularly good photograph, I might add. In a block at the corner of this article, and presumably to lead into the article, it states:

SPEECH.PARA: An organisation, funded by prominent citizens, is helping divorced fathers abduct their children and flee Australia, complete with changed identities for a new life overseas, according to a Western Australian Senator.
And she's planning to demand Government action when Parliament resumes this week.

The Senate may recall that, some four and a half years ago, I raised in this chamber the matter of an organisation called the Fathers' Organisation for Revolutionary Custody Entitlement, or FORCE. At that time, I asked a question in which I said that information that I had led me to believe that charter flights were using isolated airstrips in the north of Western Australia to smuggle out both parents and children who had been the subject of custodial orders through the Family Court of Australia. I expressed my concern that these children would be virtually forced by their parents' action to be now resident in a strange environment where their lifestyles could be totally different. If the children went without their passports, I asked what action would they be able to take at a later time to return to Australia.

That was the first and last time that I heard of FORCE until I was contacted during the week by a reporter from the Sunday Press. He informed me that the group was operating in a bigger and better organised way than ever. I now find that in this article I am quoted as saying:
But she was told this week that the group was still operating in all states 'bigger and better organised than ever'.
'If this is true, action must be taken immediately to stop those involved,' . . .

At this point I say that the person who advised me that it is operating in a bigger and better way was the reporter. I have not heard of this organisation since 1977. Leading into the story the newspaper, which is not a particularly good one-presumably it is really on the bones if it thinks that it will sell papers by raising something that is four and half years old-states:
The Senate will be asked this week to investigate a clandestine organisation which claims to have 'smuggled' hundreds of fugitive fathers and their children out of Australia.

I am quite happy to ask the Senate to investigate the matter. I was quite happy to ask it to investigate it four years ago. But if no new evidence has come forward I wonder whether there is any point in my asking for an investigation into an organisation about which I know very little. At the time I was being interviewed by telephone in Perth, from Melbourne, I was told that a number of serious allegations were made, including the fact that a boat had been picked up outside the three-mile limit. The boat contained a number of parents and their children who were on their way to goodness knows where. My immediate response was: What three-mile limit? The old limit was 12 miles and the new limit is 200 miles. So what the heck if there is a group of people outside a three-mile limit? What three-mile limit were they talking about? Allegations were made, only by the journalist, that there had been a connection between the FORCE organisation and the death of a Family Court judge. I have no way of knowing whether that is fact or fiction. I really do not care to discuss it and I do not intend to discuss it here any further. But I am concerned that I am being quoted in such a way, after raising the matter four years ago when I could not get a great deal of interest from the Press.

The story was repeated yesterday in the Sydney Morning Herald on page 3, which once again states that I am going to ask the Senate to investigate this same clandestine organisation. There are also some quotations in this article that lead me to some confusion. I am quoted as having said that I:

. . . first became aware of the activities of FORCE in 1977, but after raising the matter in Parliament had been told by the Federal Government that police investigations could not uncover sufficient evidence to lay charges.
I am a little concerned because later on in the story another person says:
'The airlifts out of the country are not as frequent as they used to be.'
The article goes on to state:
'There have only been three or four in the past four months.'
'This is because Federal authorities have privately told us that they would not go out of their way to prosecute us and there would be no great manhunts.'

That causes me a great deal of concern because it would appear that, if this story is correct, there have been three or four airlifts of children out of the country in the past three or four months. It also concerns me because some Federal authority is quoted as having made statements too. That may not in fact be true. I ask whether the veracity of the journalist who wrote this article has been questioned. I will question it now. As I said, the organisation must be really trying to sell its newspapers by sensationalism. Perhaps if it was being more practical it would have written something similar to what was contained in the Australian's leader this morning. It talks about the changes to the Family Law Act which are necessary to prevent this type of organisation operating and fostering in a society such as Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-This statement is to advise the Senate in detail of the measures undertaken by the Government, following the confirmed finding on 13 August 1981 of horse meat in a shipment of Australian boneless beef to the United States of America. This discovery, coupled with the finding in Melbourne on 21 August of kangaroo meat in cartons marked for export as boneless beef, is an extremely grave matter. The Government is determined to have all the facts of this case brought to light, to stamp out this kind of activity, to prosecute those involved, and to ensure that all possible measures are taken to prevent such activity from happening again. The tragedy of this case is the immense damage it has caused to the reputation of our meat industry, both here and overseas.

SPEECH.PARA: We are currently investigating a situation where meat bearing the markings of two of Australia's 400 licensed export establishments has been found to have been adulterated. Both establishments are based in Melbourne. Their total exports to the United States so far this year have amounted to 632 tonnes, or 0.39 per cent of total Australian shipments to the United States over the same period, amounting to 161,000 tonnes. The Australian Bureau of Animal Health is carrying out spot checks and species tests on export boneless beef in store in every State in Australia. So far, not one of these has shown any evidence of substitution. Of 742 tests taken up to 9 a.m. this morning, every single one has proved positive for beef. Without in any way trying to play down the gravity of the situation, the facts at present indicate that the great bulk of Australia's meat export industry is carrying out its trade honestly and fairly.

This is the first known case of horse or kangaroo meat having been substituted for beef. While there have been a number of broad allegations made over past years, to the knowledge of the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) not one of these has related specifically to the substitution of horse or kangaroo meat. Clearly, existing requirements and regulations governing the export meat trade have to be tightened up, and existing penalties for fraudulent activities in the trade substantially increased. We have been faced with a potentially devastating situation which has major ramifications for our $3.5 billion meat industry, and consequently for the national economy. Not only must this case be cleared up, and the offenders satisfactorily dealt with, but also the stigma hanging over the Australian meat industry must be removed once and for all. The Minister is determined that it will be.

There have been a lot of emotive statements and claims over the past two weeks including that the Government has moved too slowly on this matter. The facts do not support such claims. The Government has acted promptly, properly, decisively, and in co-operation with the United States. On 11 August 1981, the Australian Bureau of Animal Health received its first advice from the United States Department of Agriculture that horse meat was suspected in a carton of boneless beef, in San Diego, bearing the markings of Australian Meat Export Establishment 140C, Profreeze, Richmond, Melbourne. On 12 August, the movement of all export meat from Profreeze was terminated. Seven other boning rooms in the same complex were also placed under strict surveillance with thorough checks being made on their product before release for export.

The United States Department of Agriculture advised us on 13 August 1981 that laboratory tests on the 140C meat in San Diego proved positive for horse meat. Immediately we received that advice, Establishment 140C was deregistered, meaning that it can no longer export meat to anywhere in the world, and the Australian Federal Police were asked to investigate. These measures were announced publicly on that day. Immediately steps were also taken to tighten security: For example, 1,809 cartons of meat in Victoria bearing 140C markings, with a trade value of around $100,000, were seized and impounded for testing; spot checks were introduced in all States; extra meat inspector surveillance was provided at independent boning rooms and cold stores; shiploading security was increased; and checking of health certificates and all documentation was intensified.

Further measures were then developed within days. A new system was devised for security seals to be placed on cartons which will cost an estimated $1m in 1981-82. The first delivery of these seals is expected today and they will progressively be put into use forthwith. An urgent review of relevant laws and the penalties which can apply was instigated, involving senior officers of the Department of Primary Industry, the Attorney-General's Department, and the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs. Police investigations were intensified and at present there are 15 Australian Federal police, four Victorian police and one officer from the Trade Practices Commission involved. These numbers will be increased as the Commissioner requests. A special task force was set up within the Bureau of Animal Health to co-ordinate a nation-wide sampling and species testing program. The Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore), on 20 August, asked the Trade Practices Commission to investigate claims of false description in the trading of meat. Kangaroo serum was sent to the United States Department of Agriculture to assist it in its testing program.

On 1 September the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation suspended the export licence of Samsons Meat Co. (Victoria) Pty Ltd, and is continuing investigations into other companies. On 4 September 1981 the United States Department of Agriculture advised that horse meat had been confirmed in a consignment of meat from Establishment 622-Jason Meats Pty Ltd, Abbotsford, Melbourne. That establishment was immediately deregistered and the Australian Federal Police advised. All cartons labelled 622 are being seized and tested. So far, 2,533 cartons have been impounded. Because of this latest development, the Minister viewed it as essential to take special action in regard to Victoria. The Minister therefore took the decision that day to suspend the export operations of 27 independent boning rooms in Victoria. Yesterday, to strengthen further the controls, the Minister extended this suspension to include independent boning rooms in Victoria that are associated with an abattoir complex. This involves six boning rooms. The suspension became effective from midnight last night and will remain in force until the boning rooms can demonstrate adequate security measures and a satisfactory species testing program. Those who can meet the new requirements will be reinstated immediately, and will then be able to look forward to again being acceptable exporters to the United States.

There have been questions raised as to why this action did not also include those boning rooms which are registered with the registered number of an abattoir. There are 15 boning rooms in Victoria in this situation. The reason is simply that these boning rooms are part and parcel of a fully integrated operation which is under constant supervision. The overall operation is one in which the live animal is brought in, slaughtered, processed, packed, frozen, stored and subsequently loaded out on the one establishment. In other words, the integrated establishments already have a much higher degree of security. The new procedures are being applied nationally from today, and any registered establishment found not meeting them will have its operations suspended.

I now turn to legislative measures that the Government is taking forthwith. Under existing provisions, the maximum penalties for fraudulent activity or breaches in our export meat trade are totally inadequate. We will be introducing legislation into Parliament this week to bring these penalties to a realistic level. Maximum penalties under the Customs Act and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act for illegal export are to be lifted from the present $1,000 to $100,000 or five years' imprisonment, or both, on indictment under each Act. Also both Acts will provide for a maximum penalty of $5,000 or one year's imprisonment, or both, on summary conviction.

There will be a separate, new Bill-the Meat Export (Penalties) Act. This will also provide for maximum penalties of $100,000 or five years' imprisonment, or both, on indictment, for offences relating to the misuse of inspection stamps, alteration or interference with descriptions and tags, and making false or misleading statements. Similarly, it will provide for a maximum penalty of $5,000 or one year's imprisonment, or both, on summary conviction. Offences of this nature are currently covered by the Exports (Meat) Regulations, which provide for a maximum penalty of only $100. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation Act will be amended to enable the penalty provisions for breach of export licence conditions to be increased from $2,000 to a maximum of $100,000 or 5 years' imprisonment, or both, on indictment, and for a maximum of $5,000 or one year's imprisonment, or both, on summary conviction. Further legislation will be introduced at a later date to enable the Corporation to suspend an export licence immediately where prima facie evidence exists that a condition of the licence has been breached.

These measures might sound somewhat extreme, but in the opinion of the Minister and the Government, they are realistic penalties that should be imposed on anyone involved in racketeering of this nature, and in placing at risk our entire export meat trade. Such penalties also will clearly demonstrate to our trading partners that we will not tolerate fraudulent practices in this industry. The Government gave close consideration to making these legislative changes retrospective, but for reasons of legal precedence, has now decided against this. The higher penalties will apply from the date of royal assent.

In addition to the legislative changes, the Government is implementing strict new controls: Export meat will be stored in specially secured and approved cold stores, under new inventory control measures; owners of registered export establishments will be responsible for all activities conducted on their premises; meat transport vehicles and containers will be sealed, to add to the security of the packed product during transport from a boning room to an approved secure cold store or shipside.

We are examining the possibility of requiring registered export meat packers also to be licenced exporters. This would mean that packers would be responsible and accountable for their product from the time they physically pack it to the time it is loaded on ship for export. Another measure under consideration by the Bureau of Animal Health is whether the requirement of a standard one-piece meat carton will be cost effective and will further enhance security, by making re-lidding impossible. All of these measures have been set in train since 11 August, when we were first notified of possible horse meat substitution. Since that time, the Minister has had constant discussion with representatives in the livestock and meat industry. The Minister has been inundated with representations and suggestions. His concern has been to ensure that those responsible for this racket are brought to justice-to that end the Australian Federal Police are investigating-and also to ensure that the appropriate measures are instigated to prevent as far as possible such a situation occurring again.

Mr Nixon held a lengthy meeting with meat industry representatives in Melbourne last Thursday, and convened a special meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council on Friday, at which all State Ministers of agriculture were present. The Minister wanted to ensure that the initiatives being taken by the Government were considered to be appropriate and were taken after full consultation. At both his meeting with industry representatives and the Australian Agricultural Council there was general agreement on the initiatives he had taken and which he was proposing to take. The special meeting with State Ministers for agriculture was particularly relevant, because to a large degree the problem arose from and extended to areas outside the Commonwealth Government's jurisdiction, notably, State controls over knackeries and the movement of pet meat. Clearly there is an urgent and equal necessity for the States and Northern Territory to strengthen their controls in this area. This was impressed upon Ministers at the Agricultural Council meeting. It was agreed that all States and the Northern Territory immediately examine policies and practices for controlling knackeries, denaturing pet meat, and identifying game meat for human consumption. The matter will be taken further at a special meeting of the Standing Committee on Agriculture, to be held in Melbourne on 18 September. Since the problem is clearly a national one, the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) yesterday telexed all Premiers and the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory seeking their full support for an urgent examination of these areas so that rapid progress can be made at the meeting on 18 September. On this point, the Minister is pleased to say, that he has already been advised that Victoria will co-operate completely in any way possible.

Mr Nixon also makes specific mention of the fact that, from the outset, we have had daily contact and close co-operation with the United States. When the United States Special Trade Representative, Ambassador Brock, and Mr Nixon discussed this issue on 17 August in Canberra, he expressed satisfaction with the way in which the Australian Government was handling the situation. At no time have we received any complaints from the United States Administration as to the way in which we are dealing with this issue. In fact, its appreciation is on record. Following the Government's action last Friday in regard to the Victorian independent boning rooms, the United States Department of Agriculture announced the next day the immediate release on to the American market of all Australian meat except that from Victoria. About 24,000 tonnes of meat, valued at $40m has been released. We are continuing to negotiate for the earliest possible release of some 6,000 tonnes of Victorian meat still being held. The decision by the United States Department of Agriculture confirms two most significant points: One, the confidence of the United States Administration in the Australian meat export industry; and two, the success of close co-operation and consultation between our respective governments and veterinary authorities.

A senior veterinary officer from the Bureau of Animal Health has been in Washington since 1 September discussing new proposals and other technical matters with his veterinary counterparts in the United States Department of Agriculture. The USDA has also sent an officer to Australia for discussions with officials. Honourable senators will be aware that on 26 August Mr Nixon issued a statement confirming new procedures adopted by the United States to prevent any attempt at substitution of meat for the United States market. Among those procedures is a requirement for the Bureau of Animal Health to set up an approved procedure for species testing in Australia before export meat receives its final certification.

To this end the Minister and his Department are currently discussing with the USDA a detailed species testing program whereby registered premises will be divided into three risk categories with the appropriate sampling for each category as follows: One, where product is produced under a full time inspection supervision system from slaughter through to final containerisation in the one establishment with only one operator, samples be taken from 10 cartons a week on a random basis. Two, where product is produced under full time inspection supervision, but where there are leased boning rooms on the establishment, samples from 10 cartons a week of each operator's product be taken on a random basis. Three, where a product has been transferred from either an abattoir or a boning room and stored elsewhere prior to containerisation, samples from 10 cartons from each container, or from each consignment of 600 cartons, be taken.

The Government has received an interim report from the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police stating that police investigations into this case are proceeding satisfactorily. Honourable senators will no doubt be aware that one man has just been arrested and charged with 21 offences. I do not propose to canvass any details of the investigations, because it is imperative that inquiries are not jeopardised. The investigations will continue to be followed through to their conclusion as a matter of top priority. In the meantime the Government feels it is now in a position to consider whether a broader inquiry is necessary. This is based on the fact that we now have the interim police report coupled with the weekend decision of the USDA to release the majority of impounded Australian meat on to the United States market. I want to reiterate that the Government has at no time ruled out the possibility of a broader inquiry.

Having therefore considered the position and having regard to the seriousness of the allegations that have been raised, particularly allegations that people in official positions have been involved in malpractice, the Government has decided to set up a royal commission into certain aspects of the meat industry including allegations of malpractice in relation to the export of meat and to meat preparation in the State of Victoria. The Acting Prime Minister will be announcing the terms of reference when the commission is established. Victoria has agreed to take part in the royal commission. The Acting Prime Minister has sent a telex to all State Premiers and to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory inviting them to do likewise. In addition to all the measures I have detailed, the Government has decided to engage an independent consultant to conduct a comprehensive review on the effectiveness of the revised system for the documentary and physical control of export meat. The consultant is to report as soon as possible and to recommend any additional measures he feels are necessary to ensure that the revised system fully achieves the objective of ensuring to the utmost that only meat legally certified for export is in fact exported. This is, if honourable senators like, a double check, to be carried out independently, to ensure that no loophole is left for illegal exports. The question could be asked why such parallel inquiries are to proceed. The reasons are that, whilst the Government has decided on a royal commission in relation to allegations of malpractice, which could be somewhat lengthy, there is, in the interests of restoring the international credibility of our meat industry, a much more urgent and immediate need for the procedural aspects to be reviewed as promptly as possible by an independent consultant. The Minister hopes, subject to negotiations with the consultant to be appointed, to have his report within two months.

Serious allegations have been made and it is the Government's determination that they be fully and completely answered. Australia's meat industry has been severely tarnished and it is imperative that its international reputation be cleared. The Minister believes the establishment of a royal commission is the only means by which we will achieve such an aim to the satisfaction of everyone in the community. The measures I have detailed are broad ranging and decisive initiatives for the Australian meat industry. Such stringent measures have to be imposed on the honest majority, because of the fraudulent actions of a small minority. I seek leave to move a motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —People who took a close interest in the razor gang's decision pertaining to the Australian Wool Corporation received a convincing demonstration of the incompetence of the present Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). In two other areas-the affairs of the Australian Dairy Corporation in Asia Dairy Industries (Hong Kong) Ltd and now the meat export scandal, or slaughtergate scandal-we must add to the incompetence typically displayed by the Minister for Primary Industry what is at best a charge of culpable negligence. The Minister's behaviour in the Australian Dairy Corporation and meat export affairs has been similar. It has been characterised by prevarication and obfuscation. He has even used the same wording in both cases: 'It would be inappropriate for me to take any action at this time'. But in this last case-the slaughtergate affair-the consequences of his incompetence and of his culpable negligence are far more serious. They threaten, if not the survival, then certainly the prosperity of an export industry which returns income in excess of $1 billion a year. For many years-for decades-a guarantee by the Australian Department of Primary Industry as to the quality of an export commodity was accepted right around the world as just that-an ironclad guarantee of quality. Never before has it been called into question.

SPEECH.PARA: All that has now been swept away. In place of a national uniform and unquestioned system of quality control and export guarantees we have-no wonder under the circumstances-various State governments attempting to extricate their States from the confusion and damage which have flowed from the inadequacy of the Minister for Primary Industry. The Premier of New South Wales said just a couple of days ago:

The Government of New South Wales is not going to see our beef export industry go down the drain. If it is necessary to save the industry and to save the reputation of the industry in New South Wales we are prepared to go it alone. If it means that we have to promote and market our beef under our own label we are prepared to do that too. We will co-operate with the industry in New South Wales to the hilt and back it to the hilt.

That is the position into which responsible State Premiers have been forced by the failure of the Federal Minister for Primary Industry. It is well known-it is a common topic of conversation on the Sydney Stock Exchange-that people are running round with handfuls of Press clippings on the subject from the United States of America. It is highly damaging publicity which must have grave long term consequences for this major exporting industry.

This incident, celebrated although it has become, was not unprecedented. Several warnings had been received. Allegedly as far back as 1975 there were police investigations of malpractice in meat exporting establishments. Early in 1978 Senator Primmer made quite specific allegations in the Senate which received the brush-off from the then Minister for Primary industry, the present Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair), Mr Nixon's predecessor. In 1979 the Western Australian exporting firm of W. Pope and Co. was charged with falsely labelling export meat and was convicted in February 1980. The Pope racket, which was disturbingly similar in many respects to that which has been exposed in Melbourne in the last few weeks, involved changing labels in a storage room after the Commonwealth inspectors had departed. Diced mutton was put in cartons labelled as diced beef. I said at the time that we were indeed fortunate that the price of mutton was lower than the price of pork because had a firm such as Pope's chosen to put pork instead of mutton in a carton labelled beef, we could have written off the entire Middle East market. The Minister on page 7 of his statement stated:
Under existing provisions, the maximum penalties for fraudulent activity or breaches in our export meat trade are totally inadequate.

That is correct. However, it begs the question. They were just as inadequate 18 months ago when W. Pope and Co. was convicted of an equally reprehensible offence. Why did not the Minister take some action at that stage? Why did he not order a proper investigation of the information-not just allegations-given to the Senate more than three years ago by Senator Primmer? Why is the Commonwealth Police Commissioner put in a situation in which he has to admit publicly that the Australian Federal Police have been less than diligent in pursuing these inquiries? The ultimate reponsibility for all of that negligence rests with the Minister for Primary industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —He should resign.

—He should but he will not. We know that the National Country Party has absolutely no sense of shame. What ought to happen, given that a National Country Party Minister never resigns, is that he ought to be sacked by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). Of course, he would be if the Prime Minister was not a toady of the National Country Party.
—They sacked Reg Withers for less than that.
—Reg Withers was not in the National Country Party.
—And Robinson.

—Mr Eric Robinson also was sacked. They were all sacked because they were not in the National Country Party. This Prime Minister is a National Country Party toady. That is why Mr Nixon survives in the portfolio and why his predecessor survived in the portfolio for two years longer than he should have, only to be subsequently reinstated to another portfolio-of which he is also making a mess. The statement today, which purported to answer, among other things, the very serious allegations published in the Bulletin of a fortnight ago, was no answer at all. It was not an answer to, nor did it deal in any way with, the information that Senator Primmer gave to the Senate more than three years ago. For example, the Bulletin of 8 September 1981 states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Bulletin was told by a number of sources that again the police were discouraged from pursuing their investigations by senior civil servants and politicians in Canberra who, ironically, feared the impact the disclosures might have on Australia's meat export trade.

The Minister's statement fails completely to come to grips with that or any other very serious allegation in that article and other articles. Behind the aggressive facade of the Minister lurks a very mediocre politician who has maladministered every portfolio that he has ever held. The Minister's defence, the one given by proxy, for his negligence is, as was stated in the article in the Bulletin, an alleged concern that unfavourable publicity would damage Australia's export trade. He could hardly have received more unfavourable publicity for a major export than has been received in respect of this export in the last few weeks if he had deliberately designed a formula for so doing. If that is his defence he is, by his own standards, a failure at best; or, at worst, he is party to a cover-up in this instance as he was with respect to the Asia Dairy Industries affair. His defence, when given not by proxy but in person, consisted of an attempt to shove all of the blame sideways onto the Australian Federal Police and the Minister responsible for the Australian Federal Police. In an interview on Nationwide on 3 September 1981 Peter Couchman asked Mr Nixon:
But why was there no investigation? . . .
Well ask the police, don't ask me. I mean, I don't make judgments on investigations, that's not a matter for me.

The defence invoked on the Minister's behalf by others is that he was afraid of unfavourable publicity for a major export industry. His defence, put forward personally, is to try to shift the blame sideways. In the same Nationwide interview of 3 September he said:
. . . all these references have gone to the police, and the only one that I know of that has been successfully prosecuted was in Tasmania.

Quite frankly, I do not know anything about the one in Tasmania but I do know that the firm of Pope was prosecuted successfully and fined a paltry $100 in Perth in early 1980. The Minister either is attempting to mislead the public and trivialise the matter in making the statement he made on Nationwide or, I suppose with characteristic negligence and incompetence, is unaware of the successful prosecution that was launched in Perth. In any previous Australian government a Minister in the position that Mr Nixon has been in over the last couple of weeks would have resigned but since a new nadir of ministerial responsibility has been established under the present Prime Minister that course of action is no longer taken. Ministerial responsibility scarcely exists. The final bill for all of this ministerial and prime ministerial negligence and incompetence will be picked up by the thousands of innocent producers of export meat and the processors of export meat-the people who work in the abattoirs-and the honest operators ultimately will regretfully be forced to pick up the cost of this ministerial negligence and irresponsibility.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the ministerial statement regarding the meat substitution that has concerned all Australians, including this Government, producers and exporters, since 11 August this year, some 26 days ago. I do not propose to talk at length about the comments of the previous speaker, Senator Walsh, because basically they did not revolve around the matters that are dealt with in the statement now before the Senate and which are of great concern to all Australians but in typical form were a personal attack on the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon). That seems to be Senator Walsh's habit and method and if he regards it as a privilege, it is his privilege so to do, but it does very little if anything to solve the problems that confront this Government, the Opposition and the Australian producers and exporters across the board. There has been revealed for the first time an action which is highly and absolutely detrimental to the meat trade within and without Australia. I make the point that to this stage no real and effective problem has been raised by the Government or by the Opposition concerning the standards of Australian primary industry products as they compete in world markets. The Opposition, of course, is the watchdog, we are told, in this circumstance. No problem has been raised by those who are directly concerned, that is, the industry organisations themselves. It has been established that some 0.39 per cent of the meat that has been exported to the United States of America during this year has been adulterated.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to understate for one moment the seriousness of the situation. But I certainly want to state and clearly identify the fact that the Government through the Minister himself has accepted the extreme responsibility that lies with the Government and the whole of the industry in re-establishing the sort of confidence that the consuming world has in the products of Australian primary industry and particularly in this case the meat industry. Governments are aware, and this Government is aware, of the seriousness of corruption in the handling of any part of the beef export industry. It is important at this time to establish and to make clear that appropriate and severe action has been taken, and it has been taken, I believe, with considerable speed and responsibility.

Governments, producers and exporters have been, through their organisations, aware of the need for strict export controls throughout the history of Australia's contribution to the world meat trade, but today we are confronted with the fact that abuse of export standards has been clearly identified. The purpose of this statement and this debate is to bring clearly before the Australian people the sort of action that the Government is taking in the face of these serious circumstances. Australia's reputation in the world as a researcher and a breeder in the fields of grain, livestock, meat production and fibre production is, I dare say, second to none. Its reputation needs to be quickly re-established. The determination of this Government, as is clearly identifiable in the story in this statement, is to re-establish our reputation which is absolutely essential to so many areas of the Australian economy.

There is a need to intensify greatly the urgency and the comprehensive nature of the handling of the present crisis because markets are built, among many other things, on confidence. We have been confronted in recent years with the loss of very significant markets such as the United Kingdom and the European Economic Community which has meant that Australia has had to re-establish markets in other parts of the world for about 37 per cent of her export trade. We have been able to do that very successfully. One of the main reasons for this success has been the measure of confidence that the consumers of primary products in particular have in Australian produce.

I do not need to go through the history of this matter but I think it is necessary to realise there has been a quick and logical approach to the problem confronting our great meat industry. Since 11 August horse meat and kangaroo meat adulteration in beef exports to the United States of America has been identified. Even though, as I said earlier, at this stage it relates to only 0.39 per cent of the 161,000 tons that have been exported ever since that time there has been the closest co-operation with the United States authorities-that is essential-in eradicating the possibility of that sort of thing ever again occurring. It is on a realisation that such a possibility has been eradicated that the industry will most quickly be rebuilt.

It is quite clear and easy to establish that the great mass of industrialists involved in the Australian beef industry-indeed, in any section of primary industry-are honest, effective and efficient operators. It is because there has been a deviation from that sort of honesty that we as a government have found it necessary to impose very quickly the sorts of restrictions, the sorts of penalties and the new provisions concerning meat inspection that will make it, one would hope and expect, virtually impossible for anybody to get around the provisions relating to the establishment of quality in the Australian product. As I mentioned a moment ago, the United States Department of Agriculture has been in very close contact with the Minister. Largely through that contact all but some 14,000 tons of the meat which is impounded in the United States will be released in the immediate future. Indeed, had it not been possible to obtain the release of that massive amount of meat on to the American market there could well have been still further delays in the establishment of the sort of investigation which finally will reveal those who are guilty of actions which I am sure no Australian would condone, now or at any time.

I mention very briefly some of the penalties that it has been found necessary to impose as a result of the malpractices detected in the meat export trade at this time. The maximum penalties imposed under the Customs Act and the Commerce (Trade Descriptions) Act for illegal export have been raised from $1,000 to $100,000, or five years imprisonment, or both. A new Meat Export (Penalties) Act will impose a penalty of $100,000, or five years imprisonment, or both. Currently offences of the nature that we are discussing are covered by the Meat Export Control Regulations, which provide for a maximum penalty of only $100, clearly not much more than a gesture. Yet that penalty has applied throughout the reign of various governments and in the full knowledge of relevant organisations. One wonders how that can be so. Apparently those sorts of penalties have imposed sufficient restraint and have been a sufficient deterrent to this time. Clearly, it has been found necessary to increase greatly the penalty.

The Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation Act is to be amended to enable the penalty for breach of export licence conditions to be increased from $2,000 to a maximum of $100,000, or five years imprisonment, or both. At a later date, further legislation will be introduced to enable the Corporation to suspend an export licence immediately upon finding that prima facie evidence of a breach of export licence conditions exists. I could continue outlining provisions which clearly have been established in haste but which have been established properly to overcome the failure of present deterrents. I do not intend to read from further sections of the statement. I think it is sufficient to say that the exposure of malpractice in the beef export industry-namely, the substitution of kangaroo and horse meat for Australian beef-is something with which Australians, across the board, are thoroughly disgusted. It is something which Australians have required the Minister, the Government and, indeed, all appropriate organisations to rectify with great haste and in co-operation with our customer, the United States, which has been so directly involved and which in fact has brought this matter, as it were, to a head.

I believe that there can be no doubt that in well under a month the Minister has made every responsible move possible to establish a water-tight situation. In the final resort, he has decided to establish a royal commission, which must investigate to the absolute, fullest extent, the possibilities of a recurrence of the sort of malpractice that has occurred. The Minister has determined further to appoint an independent consultant to report on the matter, it is hoped, within two months. I believe that the speed with which that sort of report will avail the Government and the industry of information is essential. Whilst a royal commission permits an in-depth investigation to be undertaken, confidence must be regained and conditions must be established to enable this great industry to re-establish its position in the minds of its consumers and its customers around the world, particularly the United States of America. We have witnessed the development of a problem under, I suppose, a legislative and checking system which has been well known to governments, Federal and State, of all political persuasions, and indeed to industry organisations. In spite of all that, the malpractice has arisen and has been exposed. Every responsible measure possible has been adopted by the Minister and the Government to overcome the problem and to re-establish the sort of confidence that the industry and the rest of the community must have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —It certainly gives me no great pleasure to stand here this afternoon and recall events of three and a half years ago. I hope that no one in this chamber will think that in any way I am saying 'I told you so', because it is not my intent to adopt that line. However, it is rather interesting to recall now what I said in the adjournment debate on 7 March 1978. I repeat what I said then:

SPEECH.PARA: At times I have felt that the matters I intend to raise should not be brought before the Parliament. Indeed, in the short term a certain amount of damage to our meat export industries may be the result of a public discussion of the matters I wish to canvass at this point of time. However, if the situation as it now exists continues, I firmly believe that long term damage will be done to a major rural export industry. Therefore, the short term disadvantages have to be weighed against the long term advantages of cleaning up a gross mess in the industry.

I state here and now that the evidence given to me at that stage, irrefutable evidence from an impeccable source, in no way indicated that the substitution of buffalo, kangaroo or horse meat for beef and/or mutton was taking place. The evidence given to me at that time indicated merely that meats that had not passed before a Commonwealth inspector, meats that had not been branded for export, were being substituted for beef and were being placed in boxes marked for export. Further allegations were made about misuse of the export stamp. Since I raised that matter in 1978 it has become patently obvious that the malpractice has developed and has spread on a far wider scale in Victoria than was perceived three years ago. It is interesting to go back to some of the questions that I asked. At page 405 of the Hansard of 7 March 1978, I stated:
I ask the Minister to disclose whether the following six companies were among those named in the Commonwealth Police report.

I do wish to take time to go back over the names of those companies. They are contained in Hansard at that page. In effect, there was no reply from the then Minister for Primary Industry, Mr Sinclair, to that question. I said:
I ask the Minister: Does the Government intend to initiate further investigations into this matter?
Again, there was no reply. I asked further:
Does the Minister intend to start prosecutions on this matter?

Again, there was no reply. The following day, in answer to a Dorothy Dix question posed in the other place by the honourable member for Mallee, Mr Fisher, the then Minister for Primary Industry produced a copy of a letter from the Commonwealth Police, signed by Acting Chief Superintendent R. H. Gillespie, the officer in charge of the District of Victoria, which in part stated that investigations had been carried out but inquiries were continuing. The letter stated:
Enquiries are continuing and when further information comes to hand you will be advised accordingly.

When I looked back on this I saw that that letter was dated 16 November 1977, some four months before I raised the allegations. It is highly likely that the letter from which the Minister quoted had nothing whatsoever to do with the allegations that I raised four months later. Perhaps I was somewhat remiss in that I did not follow up these matters, but I firmly believe, having given the information I did, that it was then up to the then Minister, his staff, his departmental officials or someone from the Commonwealth Police to contact me and find out what information I could give and perhaps inquire as to the source of my information.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a responsibility of the Department of Primary Industry.

—I think, as Senator McClelland just mentioned, that it was a responsibility of the Department of Primary Industry to follow up that matter. Another disturbing feature of this matter, on looking back, is that it was the tendency of the then Minister, Mr Sinclair, to speak down to me as if I were some sort of a nincompoop. I might be a nincompoop, but it is obvious that in this case I had the facts. I had the bull by the proverbials-by the horns. In relation to the report from the Commonwealth Police from which the Minister quoted, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: However, the report from the Commonwealth Police specified that inquiries made and surveillance of suspect vehicles had failed to provide sufficient evidence for prosecution and that inquiries were continuing. No further report has been made to my Department by the Commonwealth Police. It would seem that there is no basis now for Senator Primmer's allegations. However, if he has any facts that he wishes to disclose in confidence to either the Commonwealth Police or the Department, of course they would be prepared to follow those allegations further.
At the latter end of the Minister's reply came a little gem. He said:

If Senator Primmer has any other evidence-indeed, if he has any evidence-to justify his complaints, I suggest that he submit it to either my Department or the Commonwealth Police. That might be a more equitable way of settling wild assertions in a fair and just manner.

The Minister's words have come back to haunt him. It is interesting to follow the line of attack by Ministers in this area of Australian industry. On 18 May 1976, relative to the meat industry, I posed the following question:

I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry: In view of the sudden price rise for chopper cattle at auction in Victoria following the small mass slaughter operation in the Goulburn Valley-

Honourable senators will recall that at that time the backside was out of the meat industry and farmers throughout the length and breadth of the land were being invited, and subsequently did, to take their cattle to slaughter-
will the Minister ask the Minister for Primary Industry to conduct a royal commission into all aspects of the Australian meat industry?

No, I will not, but I shall direct the honourable senator's question to the Minister and ask him whether he has anything that he might add which might help the honourable senator's knowledge of the subject.

The words of the honourable gentleman-whatever he is now-surely have come back to haunt him. At the time of that speech we were not far away from the Estimates committee hearings. As I said earlier, I made certain statements or allegations-call them what you like-relative to the misuse of the Commonwealth stamp. My colleague Senator Walsh raised at the hearing of Estimates Committee D on 5 May 1978 certain questions relative to the application of the Commonwealth export stamp to carcasses and/or export boxes of meat. Senator Walsh said:

What security provisions apply for a stamped carcass that is going to be boned out? If the carcass is stamped and subsequently boned out, what guarantee is there that the boned-out carcass which is finally bundled up in a box is the same carcass as the one which was intially stamped as being fit for export?
An officer of the Department, Mr Hart, replied:

I think it is done by keeping the stamps under control. The stamps are only applied to meat under the direct supervision of an inspector after the meat has been passed as fit for human consumption. The numbers of stamps are known; they are kept under lock and key overnight by the inspection service and reissued the next morning.

That is a rather strange statement. It is just as well that Mr Hart used the words 'I think' because that is not what has been happening to the export stamps. It is interesting to follow up the report of the Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems 1980-the Kelly report, as it subsequently became known. Mr Kelly's Committee pointed the finger at many areas of malpractice, or perceived mispractice, in the meat industry. In relation to the question of the export stamp the report had this to say at page 41:
We were also told that, in many if not all cases, the 'Australia Approved' stamp was provided by works management, and if a new stamp was required, the inspectors obtained it from management.
The recommendation of the Committee is summed up in four words:

It is obvious that the Minister and his Department have known since that report came out in January 1980-over 18 months ago-of that report's recommendation and again nothing has been done. Let us look at what has been going on lately. I refer to an interview which took place on the program Nationwide on 3 September 1981. Peter Couchman, the anchorman of that program, had this to say:
David Ransom today talked to Doug Hawkins, who's the Victorian President of the Institute of Health Surveyors.

The relevant authorities have known for the past two years that horsemeat has been used or-in the human food chain on the way to manufacturers, not necessarily as the result of the actions of the Institute. We have been involved with authorities in the matters and we have knowledge that they have been aware as we have been aware.
Which authorities and exactly what have they known?
Oh the Department of Agriculture have known-that's the Victorian Department of Agriculture and the Health Commission of Victoria. Officers of those departments have known.
Well the shame of it is they haven't been able to do anything about it, because as the law stands in Victoria nothing can be done.

That was the result of a protracted debate between certain groups of public servants in Victoria, one of whom succeeded in having the Health Act amended in 1978. I will not go further into that. The Nationwide transcript continues:
David Ransom: Just how widespread has the substitution of horse and kangaroo meat for beef been in this State?

Mr Hawkins: Well that's just a matter of conjunction, to be quite honest. We've had several instances of it, we've recently found that perhaps manufacturers have even been canvassing knackeries for the supply of horse and kangaroo meat-mainly horsemeat from knackeries-for use in manufactured goods.
That is not news in Victoria, either. Ministers have known about that because the Melbourne Age of Wednesday, 6 February carried the headline, 'Police act on meat racket'. The article states:
The State Government has ordered an urgent police inquiry into the sale of meat which it suspects could be diseased.
Police have been told that some of the meat, from dead, sick or injured animals, is being sold as small goods in Victorian supermarkets.
The inquiry, which was ordered late last year, was kept secret because of fears that it would disrupt meat sales and exports.

That is a great description of what was going on. The then Minister for Agriculture in Victoria was the honourable member for Warrnambool, the Honourable Ian Smith. Like his Federal counterparts in Canberra, Mr Smith got a little uptight when the Age exposed the story. He did something similar to what Mr Sinclair and the now Sir Robert Cotton did to me a couple of years earlier. In the Melbourne Age of 7 February 1980, it is stated:
Mr Smith said yesterday's article in 'The Age' would affect Victorian meat sales.

'What makes me cross with your article is that you may have done tens of millions of dollars worth of damage, apart from the rescue operations we have tried to do today, because our export abattoirs today, of course, will come under closer surveillance by countries wanting to import our meat,' he said.

So, instead of copping it, getting on to his Department and getting legislation through the Parliament to amend the Act and to clean up the racket, Mr Smith goes on record and blames the newspaper that ran the article exposing the malpractice. As I said before, that is very typical of his Federal counterparts in this place; it is exactly the same sort of thing that they have been doing for years. In today's Australian under the heading, 'Man offered car, $4,000. ''Threats and bribes'' used to hush up meat scandal', we read, in part:

In Perth, Mr Watson-Bates, of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union, said he could remember three occasions on which he had complained of meat substitution but had been told to keep quiet about it.
He said: 'They (Department of Primary Industry officials) always told me to tone it down because they didn't want unfavourable publicity.
'I can understand why they did not want to make these things public, but what I cannot understand is why they never changed the penalties, or tightened security.'
Mr Watson-Bates said, as far as he knew, there was now no substitution in Western Australia.
'But substitution has been going on for at least five years, and the Department knew about it,' he said.

Statements similar to these made by Mr Watson-Bates have been repeated throughout the length and breadth of the industry. People high up in the trade have been claiming for years that meat substitution has been going on. Regrettably, for reasons best known to themselves, they have not been prepared to name people, times and dates. The meat substitution racket has been common knowledge right throughout the industry. Meat industry barons and departmental people at all levels have known of it. Departmental officers have made reports but nothing has happened. For reasons best known to the people involved, somewhere the system has clagged up. The allegations and the stories have been swept under the carpet. Frankly, I am convinced that the finger should point right at the top of the tree. I make no bones about that whatsoever. It was interesting to read the article by Alan Reid, Sam Lipski and Peter Samuel in the last edition of the Bulletin. That article states:

The Commonwealth Police were given to understand-some individuals then in the force may have been told bluntly-that it should 'go quietly' on inquiries dealing with irregular practices in the meat trade. The Commonwealth feared that publicity, inevitable if prosecutions were launched, might gravely damage Australia's valuable United States export market.
The Australian Police, who succeeded the Commonwealth Police, were apparently subjected later to the same discouragement and frustration . . .
Despite almost monthly reminder letters to the Commonwealth authorities, it was 18 months before they got permission to proceed with the prosecution, which was successful.
That relates to evidence which the authorities had found and which ultimately led to that prosecution. The article goes on:
Against this background, it is easy to understand why later informants about irregular practices in the meat export trade were puzzled by the lack of investigative zeal of the police.

It is also interesting to note that amongst the people who gave evidence to the Commonwealth Police was a Mr Maurice Williams, the Liberal member of the Legislative Assembly for Doncaster in Melbourne. He gave that information to the police in November 1979. Nothing seems to have happened as a result of that. All along the line there has been cover up, cover up and more cover up. In latter day endeavours to do something about the problem, the Minister for Primary Industry has forced the closure of boning rooms in Victoria. It seems as though the innocent are being made to pay for the guilty. The Minister has, in effect, stood the law on its head. He has said: 'Thou shalt be guilty until thou prove thyself innocent'. As I said, the good go down with the bad. Frankly, one of the big problems of the meat industry in Victoria has been the expansion of boning rooms. They have sprung up hither, thither and yon and I guess they are one of the great banes of the lives of inspectors and others who try to keep a watch on the situation. There is no doubt that the bulk of those boning rooms are clean and are doing the job they set out to do without breaking the law. Of course, until the guilty ones are found everybody is under suspicion.

I do not want to say too much more at this juncture. The bulk of what I said in 1978 has proved to be true. It is a tragedy that the Government has taken so long to act. In regard to ministerial reponsibility, it is a shame that two Ministers have neglected to take action. It is a shame that the Commonwealth Police may not have been as diligent as they could have been. However, as I said earlier, I heartily concur with what the Reid article in the Bulletin has to say. I believe the finger can be pointed right up at the top of the tree. Actions have been taken to head off, to procrastinate and to sweep under the carpet allegations that have been made. They are more than allegations, they are facts of life. We note now that the Minister proposes to establish a royal commission. I called for a royal commission in 1978. After thinking about this over the last week or two I am somewhat concerned as to whether that is the right way to go about it. Royal commissions tend to drag on and in some ways they can be told what to find out. I hope for the sake of the future of the meat industry in Australia that the people who draw up the terms of reference for any royal commission that might be conducted are not the people who have been hiding the facts about the problems in the meat industry over the last five years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats welcome at last a statement from the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) in relation to this major industry, certainly a major export industry in my State. Unfortunately, the statement starts out as more a justification than an elucidation of what happened in the actual context of Australia and the meat industry. A great deal of the statement initially directs itself to looking at increased penalties. The Minister obviously feels the necessity for making at least some show in relation to this matter and suggests that heavier penalties equate with tough action on the part of the Government. The unfortunate part about that, of course, if we are looking only at penalties and at increasing them is that they are much more concerned with the cure than with the prevention of the problem.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem with the meat export industry is not that we can catch the culprits-although we do not seem to have been able to do that very well-or not that we can then take them through the courts and penalise them. Rather, the problem with the industry is that we are in danger of losing important export markets in the United States. The problem does not lie with the culprits at home but much more with the perception of our industry abroad.
The Minister's statement then moves on to what else the Government will do, it having increased the penalties. Its next move is to set up a royal commission. In his statement the Minister said:
. . . the Government has decided to set up a royal commission into certain aspects of the meat industry . . .
Which aspects we are not told-
including allegations of malpractice in relation to the export of meat and to meat preparation in the State of Victoria.

We are then told that the Acting Prime Minister (Mr Anthony) will announce the terms of reference later. It is to be hoped that those terms of reference are not the ones which one might be able to infer from the Minister's statement. It is to be hoped that the royal commission will not limit itself to looking at the allegations of malpractice in the meat industry and will not limit itself to the State of Victoria. If either of those things occurs in the terms of reference, then those terms of reference and the royal commission will be a waste of time and will not re-establish our bona fides in the United States meat market. Presumably the Minister-certainly, statements from Senator Scott would seem to indicate this-suggests that the Government has felt that some problems exist in relation to this matter and has decided to move on to yet another step, that is, to engage an independent consultant 'to conduct a comprehensive review of the effectiveness of the revised system for the documentary and physical control of export meat.'

In 1972, a select committee of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly which looked into the meat industry brought down a report. In 1973 there was a committee of inquiry into joint arrangements for meat inspection in New South Wales. In 1975, the Administrative Review Committee-the Bland report-as part of its brief also looked at the meat inspection process. Also in 1975 there was the working party of State and Commonwealth officers which investigated the feasibility of the integration of meat inspection services in Victoria. In 1977 there was the Western Australian Royal Commission into the Meat Industry. Also in 1977 there was the Booz, Allen, Hamilton report into United States meat inspection arrangements. In 1978 there was the Prices Justification Tribunal report into beef marketing and processing. In 1979 we had an investigation into disease track back methods in cattle. The report of the Australian Bureau of Animal Health, also looked into much the same type of area. In 1980 we had the report of the committee of inquiry to examine Commonwealth and State meat inspection systems. Now in 1981, in the ninth consecutive year of reports, we are told that the Government proposes to have an independent consultant look again into the meat industry. The meat industry does not need any more reports. We have enough reports to export, if we are really interested in that. What we need is some action. We have had nine years of reports, and now we are to have a royal commission and another independent consultant.

I refer the Senate to the actual report to which I want to make reference. It is the report of the Committee of Inquiry to Examine Commonwealth and State Meat Inspection Systems. This report was brought down in the Senate on 28 February last year. It was still listed on the Notice Paper on 18 September. So much for the interest of the Government in looking into this particular aspect of the meat industry. But let us not be cynical about it. Surely, when that report was brought down, it was not brought down merely to silence yet again the stirrings in the Senate, particularly on the part of Senator Primmer and others, that something ought to be done about this matter. Let us not say that that was the reason for having yet another inquiry. The committee of inquiry was asked to investigate and report to the Minister for Primary Industry on the following matters:
(a) The merits and demerits of the meat inspection system as presently operated by State and Federal bodies;
(b) whether the present system of meat inspection and administration should be retained and, if so, with or without modification;
(c) an alternative system if the present meat inspection administration system should not be retained;
(d) the recommended organisational structure and control of an alternative system . . .

Those people duly went away and did their homework, and they presented a report. The report was tabled in the Senate on 28 February and has sat-in fact, I managed to get a copy of the report covered in dust-where it was laid down ever since. Are we again to see a royal commission and an independent consultant bring forward yet more paper and yet more reports with no action? On the last nine years' worth of reports, I think the conclusion that must be drawn is that we are to have yet more paper but no action.

I suggest that the Minister's statement leaves aside one crucial element, that is, that the obvious place to start looking into this matter is in the Commonwealth meat inspection service. The fact that substitution took place at all would suggest that there is something wrong with the meat inspection service. We are not talking about intangibles. We are talking about very tangible elements-boxes and boxes and warehouses full of meat. Meat is not the type of thing which can be spirited away and changed around fairly rapidly. If, in fact, it has been changed around, and of course anybody who knows anything about the industry knows-the Minister knew, the reports for nine years have told us so, and this report tells us so again-that the lids from boxes of meat with an 'Australian approved' stamp on them can be removed and simply changed across to another box which has kangaroo meat or another substitute in it. We have known that for nine years, yet there has been no action.

The Minister says in his statement that this matter has been brought to his attention only in recent times. It has not been brought to his attention in recent times. If we want to be factual about the matter, it was brought to his attention on 28 February last year in the report which was tabled in the Senate. How can the Minister then put down a statement which says that this matter has only just come to his attention? If the reports to this chamber are to mean anything, surely they are to mean that the Minister who called for the report actually reads the report. If they do not mean that, why are we being told yet again that we are to have an independent consultant and a royal commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting I was referring to the two issues in the statement brought forward by the Minister about which the Australian Democrats are concerned. The first relates to the royal commission and the other to the independent consultant. We certainly hope, given the nine years in which reports have been presented, that this time the Government will take note of the independent consultant. We hope it will also read the report of the committee of inquiry to examine Commonwealth and State meat inspection systems. I believe that report contains the answer to the problems that have arisen and to the dual meat inspection process which has been instrumental in causing at least some of the criminal practices which have occurred in Australia to date.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate that we support quite strongly the appointment of a royal commission, but we hope that the royal commission's terms of reference will be sufficiently broad and all-encompassing so that rather than looking just at Victoria it will look at every State and take note of the problems in every State. We hope the report of the royal commission will concur with the recent report so that some time before the end of this year the Government will bring forward the proposal which is contained in that report, and that is the setting up of a single meat inspection system-the Australian Meat Inspection Service. This will amalgamate the Commonwealth and State inspection systems in such a way as to overcome all those demarcation disputes which have so bedevilled the inquiries and the various inspection services to date. We commend the Government for at last acceding to what I believe are the interests of the meat industry and the people of Australia and setting up a royal commission to inquire into what must be one of the most regrettable incidents in that industry and which, on the face of it if the Government had accepted its own reports, could have been avoided and certainly should have been avoided. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

—If we are getting to the matter of who will be given leave and who will not, I would remind honourable senators on the Opposition side that two can play at that.
