DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) nominating Senator Hamer to be a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Hamer be appointed a member of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, as contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 9 of 1981, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed, on the grounds that-
(a) the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances has found that the Ordinance does unduly trespass on the rights and liberties of citizens;
(b) the Minister for the Capital Territory has given an undertaking that the Ordinance will be replaced before Anzac Day 1982; and
(c) the Ordinance is selective in its operation, having effect only in relation to Anzac Day marches.

This is not the first time that I have spoken in this chamber in criticism of the Ordinance I am now seeking to disallow. When the ordinance was first formulated, introduced and implemented, there was an adjournment debate in this place during which my colleague Senator Evans and I spelt out our objections to the whole procedure and our objections to the Ordinance itself. I do not propose to traverse the same ground. But since our first criticisms of this piece of delegated legislation, everything that has happened in connection with it has confirmed my view and the view of the Australian Labor Party that this Ordinance ought never to have been drafted, ought never to have been introduced in the way it was and ought now to be disallowed by this Senate on the grounds that it is unacceptable in terms of the criteria of delegated legislation. It serves no useful purpose and its endorsement by this Senate would be, I believe, a dereliction of duty on the part of this chamber.

I would like to make clear that this is not the time at which I or, I hope, any other senator will canvass the merits of the various arguments that were put concerning the Ordinance. In other words, the Ordinance which was introduced to prevent a certain group of citizens from participating in the Anzac Day march ought to be considered by the Senate this evening as a piece of legislation. I do not propose here to put the case of the Returned Services League for wanting the Ordinance. I do not believe that is relevant. I do not expect to put the case of the organisation known as Wimmin Against Rape, which was prevented by the Ordinance from participating in the Anzac Day march. Those matters are not at issue. The point of view of Wimmin Against Rape is not at issue and the point of view of the RSL is not at issue. What is at issue is whether this piece of legislation was properly drawn up, whether it was drawn up in accordance with the criteria of delegated legislation, whether it would serve any useful purpose and whether it deserves endorsement by this chamber. I think anyone who is familiar with the Ordinance and events that have occurred subsequently would have to agree with that.

The Senate should not endorse this legislation. The Senate should disallow it because it is bad legislation. It is bad in its objectives, it is bad in its effect on the community, its method of preparation was bad, its implementation has been bad and its contents are bad. Let me explain what I mean. The Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, had two major objectives when he introduced this legislation. The first objective was to deny the civil liberties of a certain group of citizens; that is, he wished to bring about a special legislative denial of the rights of a group of women who wished to join the Anzac Day march in order to commemorate those women who were victims of rape in war. I think that the objective of denying the rights of people to participate in the Anzac Day ceremony in the way they wished to do is a bad objective.

But there was another objective which I think was even worse than the first one, and that was to express in legislative form the deeply felt, virulent prejudices of the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, against the whole feminist movement. If that sounds like an exaggerated claim to honourable senators I would ask them to recall the remarks made by the Minister on the radio program AM.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember it.

—My colleague Senator Grimes says by way of interjection that he remembers it, and I am sure he would. I know that anyone who heard the performance would have been appalled and scandalised that a Minister of the Crown would take the opportunity to abuse the national broadcasting service in the way he did. He engaged in most vile character assassination of the women who attempted or wished to join the march. He made wild allegations on the program that the women who were seeking to commemorate Anzac Day in this way were Marxists, lesbians and so on. It was a disgraceful performance. It was because of that performance that I say here tonight that one of the Minister's major objectives in introducing this totally gratuitous and unnecessary piece of legislation--
—Why don't you speak to us all?

—I am very pleased that the Minister is paying attention to my remarks. The prejudice and the viciousness of Mr Hodgman's attack on the women's movement-indeed, on any women who do not happen to meet his peculiarly narrow and repressive view of what women ought to do-is expressed in this piece of legislation. For that reason, too, I believe that the Senate should disallow it. I do not think that the Senate is here to endorse or to ratify legislation that merely expresses the private prejudices of a Minister against a certain group in the community. I will be very interested to hear what Senator Missen has to say about that point.

SPEECH.PARA: The other objectionable aspect of the legislation is that it singled out as a special case a particular public event in the Australian Capital Territory. Our objection to that kind of legislative process was spelt out very competently by my colleague Senator Evans on the occasion I previously referred to. There was never any need to have special legislation to maintain law and order during the Anzac Day march. As Senator Evans pointed out at great length, there is a whole plethora of law and order legislation in this Territory which has been extremely successful in maintaining order at public occasions, such as Anzac Day and the many rallies, marches and public events that occur and have occurred in this Territory for many years, certainly in the period that I have represented it. So the legislation was never necessary. It is a very bad principle to introduce a law to cover a specific event.

I have outlined the objectives of the legislation with which I take issue. However, there are other objectionable aspects of the Ordinance. One is the way it was prepared. It appeared overnight. There was no proper consultation. The Minister did not consult with members of the locally elected House of Assembly to see what were their views on it. The Minister did not consult with the Federal representatives of the Australian Capital Territory. For example, he did not consult with my colleague from the Australian Capital Territory, Senator Margaret Reid, who at that time I believe, was senator-elect for the Australian Capital Territory. There was no consultation at all. The legislation was simply dreamt up by the Minister as an hysterical response to his views that women were seeking to commemorate Anzac Day in a certain way.

As has been pointed out in this chamber, the legislation introduced a serious criminal offence with serious criminal penalties for citizens of the Australian Capital Territory by an Executive order. There was no examination of it by an elected body. No opportunity was given for the legislation to be examined by the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. The proper process of legislating in respect of criminal offences for citizens of my Territory was totally ignored and circumvented. This was absolutely unacceptable. It was really the content of the legislation itself, of course, which was so objectionable. As has been said in this place before, it is broad and vague and imposes impossible tasks on the police who have to implement it. The legislation could be interpreted in any number of ways, thus allowing the opportunity for all kinds of anomalous and unjust treatment of citizens to arise, as I believe has happened. There was never any need for the legislation. The way it was drawn up was objectionable, its objectives are objectionable and its contents are objectionable.

I must point out at this stage that criticism of the nature and content of this Ordinance certainly has not been restricted to this chamber. I would like to place on record a report that appeared in the Canberra Times of the first trial in the magistrates court of one of my constituents who was charged under this Ordinance. The report in the Canberra Times of 6 August this year states:

The first prosecution completed against a person arrested during a protest by Women Against Rape at the Anzac Day ceremony ended yesterday with the defendant, Miss Lyn Lenox, acquitted on all three charges.

Mr Dobson, SM, in Canberra Petty Sessions, said he did not have to rule whether the official ceremony had been authorised properly by the RSL, or whether the preconditions had existed for police to order the women not to march; he found, on the evidence, that the prosecution had proved neither a failure to disobey a direction nor that the woman was at the time of her arrest engaging in conduct likely to give offence to persons taking part in the official parade.
He dismissed also an alternative charge pressed by the prosecution-that Miss Lenox had attempted to disobey a police direction.
In handing down his decision, Mr Dobson was critical of the framing of the amendments to the Traffic Ordinance made shortly before Anzac Day.
His sympathy in the case went to the police, he said.

Honourable senators might recall that I made exactly the same point in an earlier speech. I said that the police were given an impossible task to perform. Mr Dobson confirmed this. The report continued:
Every time someone wanted to push a wheel-barrow in Canberra, be it uranium protestors, Aborigines, university students or the Women Against Rape, it was the police who had to bear the burden.

They were not helped by legislation such as he had to consider in this case. If the legislature had wanted to prevent activities such as the women wished to engaged in, it could have done so. He was not the legislature and had to enforce the Ordinance as it was.
He awarded costs totalling $600 to Miss Lenox.

In dismissing the alternative charge, Mr Dobson commented the charge might have been sustainable had police asked Miss Lenox what she was intending to do in brushing past them. For all he knew, she might have been going home.

The magistrate's view of the Ordinance is very clear. It was unfair on the police, it was unable to be implemented and no prosecution in that case could be made. In a second case, a person who was arrested under the Ordinance was given a six months' good behaviour bond by a different magistrate. The magistrate said:
. . . If I was a schoolteacher I'd probably keep you in after school.

That indicates the degree of seriousness he attached to his consideration of the so-called offence. It is very clear that from the point of view of the magistrates the legislation is insupportable and not the sort of thing the Senate ought to be endorsing. At this stage I repeat my disappointment that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances did not itself recommend the disallowance. As honourable senators will recall the Senate Standing Committee was critical of the Ordinance and found that it unduly trespassed on personal liberties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish. I am the Chairman of that Committee. You quote where it found that. I am speechless.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, if I may continue? The Committee was critical of the Ordinance.
—You are misleading the Senate.

—I will find the correspondence and table it later. Senator Lewis is getting far too excited. The Committee made suggestions to the Minister for the Capital Territory. When the Chairman of the Committee brought its findings before the Senate he said that the Committee would not recommend that the Ordinance be disallowed because the Minister had made certain undertakings to the Committee. I have here a copy of the letter from Mr Hodgman to Senator Lewis, the Chairman of the Committee, where he acknowledged some of the criticisms. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I confirm my opinion that it is desirable that there should be a Code covering the law relating to parades, processions and assemblies, generally, in the Australian Capital Territory.

I am more than happy to give your Committee an undertaking that it is my intention to give instructions for the preparation of a general Ordinance, in effect setting out a Code covering the law relating to parades, processions and assemblies, generally, in the Australian Capital Territory. This will be done as expeditiously as possible, and I further indicate that it is my intention to refer the proposed Ordinance to the House of Assembly and also to your Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is wrong with that?

—As far as I know this has not happened. I have not seen such a draft. I would be very surprised if Senator Missen has seen such a draft. My colleagues in the House of Assembly who were promised a draft have not seen such a draft. I do not believe that such a draft exists. I do not believe that the Minister has fulfilled his undertaking to as expeditiously as possible bring in a draft for a new ordinance which would take account of the criticisms of the Committee and of other criticisms. Quite clearly the undertaking has not been fulfilled. We are in a situation where we have a ludicrous Ordinance which most people now agree should never have been introduced. Citizens are being charged under this Ordinance. In one case a bond was imposed. The new legislation has not appeared.

SPEECH.PARA: What would we achieve by disallowing the Ordinance? What we would achieve by this is the expression of the view by the Senate that the Ordinance ought never to have existed. It served no useful purpose. It caused a great deal of trouble in the community and a great deal of polarisation of opinion. I believe the whole episode damaged the reputation of the Returned Services League in this Territory. I am sorry for this. I think the RSL is a useful organisation. Certainly in conducting the Anzac Day ceremonies it is undertaking a function which people in the community wish it to do. The Ordinance has caused nothing but trouble. It has been criticised on legal and political grounds. It ought not to stay on the statute books. I remind honourable senators that it was, in effect, only introduced in respect of last Anzac Day. For what it is worth the Minister's undertaking is that the Ordinance will not be in existence for the next Anzac Day. Why are we here in this Senate expected to endorse the legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —You are only going through the motions, though, aren't you?

—I hope that Senator Missen will support my motion. I find it very hard to understand how the honourable senator could defend this piece of legislation in the light of subsequent remarks by magistrates. I want to speak particularly in my concluding remarks as a Senator for the Australian Capital Territory. We have no self-governing body in the Australian Capital Territory to make laws for the public order and peace and for the well-being of the community. Legislation is made in the Federal Parliament or it is made by the Minister for the Capital Territory acting with executive powers. I think we must take very seriously our role of legislating specifically for the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory. I ask honourable senators to consider whether this Ordinance is in the interests of the Australian Capital Territory; whether it is the sort of legislation that we as a Senate want the people in the Australian Capital Territory to have; and whether we are prepared to defend it. Because if we allow the legislation to go through we ought to be able to defend it. I ask honourable senators to consider their role as legislators specifically as it applies to the Australian Capital Territory. It is widely known of course that the Australian Labor Party believes there ought to be a self-governing body in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe the Australian Democrats endorse our views in this respect. At this stage there is no such body. This Senate has the power to make good laws for the peace and order of the Territory and to disallow bad laws. It is very clear we have this power. It is clear this is not a good law and it is not defensible in any way. It ought to be disallowed. I urge honourable senators to consider my remarks seriously and to support my motion for disallowance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating a motion by Senator Ryan to the effect that the Australian Capital Territory Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance 1981 be disallowed. Firstly, I will deal with one matter raised by Senator Ryan, namely, her claim that the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances found the Ordinance contrary to its principles. How could that be? This bipartisan Committee examined the Ordinance at great length. That included a consideration of a large number of submissions from many people. Also a number of Committee members were interviewed by certain women who had a vital interest in this Ordinance. After lengthy examination the Committee unanimously decided not to move for its disallowance. For Senator Ryan to come in here and say that the Committee found the regulation was contrary to its principles is to mislead the Senate. She referred to some criticism of the Ordinance by members of the Committee. Of course, the Committee considers ordinances in a way which leads members to find criticisms. That is different from finding that the ordinance is contrary to the Committee's principles.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Ryan referred to the fact that the Committee obtained from the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman)-at the Committee's request-an undertaking to introduce a code relating to processions in the Australian Capital Territory. This will be introduced before next Anzac Day 1982. On that point I refer Senator Ryan to a statement by Senator Cavanagh on 14 May 1981, page 2047 of Hansard in a debate on the Committee's report. He states:

The Committee is of the opinion that there should not be a special law for Anzac Day if there is not one for, say, a Labour Day procession. Why should there be particular laws for particular occasions?

Of course, that is a criticism of the Ordinance but not a criticism that suggests that the Ordinance is contrary to the principles of the Committee. Many people, particularly those from other countries, seem to be at a loss as to why Australia commemorates one of the worst military adventures in its history.

Recently I spoke to a veteran about his opinion of Anzac Day and its meaning. In effect, although he acknowledged that Anzac Day has different meanings for different people, depending on their individual experiences, he told me that he thought its real significance was that it did not commemorate victory, the cessation of war, the glorification of war, the mass extermination of populations, the gruesome and barbaric attacks on civilian populations, particularly women and children, or any of the other frailties of human nature or horrors of war. The Anzac dawn service, with its special remembrance of fallen comrades, the march and the reunions reflected for him only one aspect of war, personal involvement. I believe that if that simple proposition were put to most returned servicemen, they would agree that it was central to their commemoration of Anzac Day.

I could recite the history of Gallipoli and the reasons for the commemoration of Anzac Day but I say simply that the survivors of Anzac fought to preserve human rights, freedom of thought, freedom of conscience and freedom of religion-sample issues for which, as Australians, they saw it as their duty to fight. Those survivors are entitled, in their way, to remember Anzac Day as best they may. They have certain rights, just as do people who wish to dissent. I have not the slightest doubt that those who commemorate Anzac Day in this way would be among the first to defend the right of people to engage in dissent, provided they did not infringe upon the liberties or rights of others. They might not express it in the words of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. In fact, they would be more likely to talk about championing underdogs. Nevertheless, they would argue forcibly in defence of the rights for which they fought.

However, those who commemorate Anzac Day also have their rights. One is the right to decide whom they will invite to participate in the commemoration. In the past they have chosen to invite widows and children of returned servicemen to wear their husband's or father's medals and join them in the march. In some areas they have chosen to invite selected youth groups to join them. The form of service and march varies from State to State and from town to town. These people are exercising their rights.

The very core of Anzac Day is personal involvement by returned servicemen and women. Gate-crashing an Anzac Day march may be one way of gaining publicity for a particular issue, but it infringes upon the rights of those who have earned the right to march, and thus is a breach of the universal Declaration of Human Rights. One result of World War II, and an event which followed the signing of the Atlantic Charter, was the development and declaration of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which recognises, that in accordance with the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, the ideal of free human beings enjoying civil and political freedom and freedom from fear and want, can be achieved only if conditions are created whereby everyone may enjoy his civil and political rights as well as his economic, social and cultural rights. In particular, I refer to article 18 of the Covenant, which I might paraphrase as:
Freedom to manifest ones . . . beliefs may be subject only to such limitations as are prescribed by law and are necessary to protect . . . the fundamental rights and freedoms of others.
Everyone shall have the right to freedom of expression . . .
That is qualified by a further provision, as follows:
The reference is to the rights of freedom of expression and so on-
. . . may therefore be subject to certain restrictions . . . as . . . are necessary:
For respect of the rights . . . of others;
For the protection of national security or of public order . . .

Since 1942, the Returned Services League has conducted a traditional Anzac Day march in the Australian Capital Territory. Until 1979 that march comprised war veterans and others who formed in the streets and then marched in a parade to the War Memorial to take part in a traditional Anzac Day ceremony. In 1979 a group of women calling themselves Women Against Rape pre-empted the Anzac Day march and ceremony and laid a wreath on the Stone of Remembrance in memory of women raped in war.

On Anzac Day 1980, a group of women from the same organisation attempted to join the marching veterans, and upon refusing to desist in their attempts were arrested by the Commonwealth Police, who feared a disturbance. They were charged and found guilty before the Court of Petty Sessions but an appeal to the Supreme Court was successful and the convictions were dismissed.

In April 1981, evidence was received by the President of the RSL that a large number of women would again attempt to join the Anzac Day march, with a view to disrupting it. The Australian Federal Police indicated that in light of this information they wanted powers which would enable them to act quickly in the event of the parade's being subject to disruption. It was decided to amend the Traffic Ordinance. What eventuated was the Ordinance that we are now discussing. New Section 23A created an offence of disturbing or disrupting an Anzac Day parade or an observance or ceremony conducted at or near the Australian War Memorial.

Here, then, we have clearly a conflict of rights. We know that the result of that Ordinance was the arrest of a number of women from the Women Against Rape organisation. I have no hesitation in saying to the Senate that I have considerable sympathy for the aims of Women Against Rape, but their rights to demonstrate must be balanced against the rights of our returned servicemen and servicewomen to commemorate their personal involvement in Anzac Day with dignity and without disruption. Those who want to exercise their rights to publicise a particular aspect of war or anything else that is not appropriate to Anzac Day and the personal involvement that is central to that day should do so elsewhere. We owe that debt to all who served, and in particular to those who fell in battle and to the widows and children they left behind. I shall be voting to uphold the Ordinance.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will be supporting the disallowance of the Australian Capital Territory Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance, basically on the ground that we do not believe that, on balance, it is just. We have given consideration to the points that have been put by the Government and believe that certainly they contain substance. What we have here is an example of the unfortunate situation that often arises when people with genuinely held beliefs, beliefs which are considered respectable within the community, come into conflict. I do not intend to go over the issues that arose on Anzac Day in the Australian Capital Territory. I do not believe that they are necessarily pertinent to the issue before us.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that laws must not only be just but also must be seen to be just. In the circumstances, it is fairly obvious that we have here a specialised law for the commemoration or celebration of a particular day by a particular group of people. An ordinance of this type is not provided for other such days. Therefore, we believe that if such a ordinance is to be brought forward, extremely weighty evidence must be presented as to why such a special exemption should be made. We do not believe that such arguments have been advanced.

Already there are public order provisions regarding marches and demonstrations. These are adequate in other circumstances and presumably would be adequate in this circumstance. If not, the Government ought to have brought forward a general amendment rather than a specific one, to govern problems involving marches and demonstrations on all occasions, not simply Anzac Day. However, it seems that the Government felt that those public order provisions were adequate at times other than Anzac Day. It did not say why there should be some strengthening of the law to have effect on Anzac Day. One can only assume therefore that the reason for movement on this Ordinance was the failure of prosecutions in relation to events on the preceding Anzac Day when demonstrations of a kind took place. However, if that was the reason the Government brought forward this Ordinance it has failed to achieve its objective. It failed because the prosections which were launched under this Ordinance were not successful and, as Senator Ryan has already pointed out, the Ordinance was criticised by the magistrate who dealt with the prosecutions. In fact, he seemed to be asking in as polite a way as possible: 'What could the Minister have been thinking about when he introduced such a silly ordinance'.

I think the Ordinance was introduced by the Minister, if we may give him the benefit of the doubt, under some considerable pressure by the Returned Services League which was concerned about the good order and management of Anzac Day proceedings, and I believe that is a reasonable type of stance for the RSL to take. However, I do not believe the Government's response to that stance was reasonable. I believe further discussions with the various groups which were involved would have ascertained, as we now know with hindsight, that the women were content to march silently and orderly and that they wished merely to lay wreaths to commemorate what they saw as one aspect of war. We know that now, and we also know that the hullabaloo that went on at the time was a fabrication of various people's excited imagination.

If there had been further discussion I believe the Ordinance would not have been necessary, the RSL would have been satisfied in its own mind that its march would not be disrupted and the members of Women Against Rape would have been able to march on that day and to make, I believe, a dignified demonstration of their beliefs. I believe in that case public order would have been maintained and the various points that people were attempting to make on that day could have been made in harmony. As it was I think the Government introduced into this sacred day in Australia a highly discordant political note and I believe it is there that the problem really lies. I do not believe anybody enjoyed any part of the episode whatsoever. I think we all regret the episode that occurred. We now know-I think everybody is in agreement with this-that the disruption would not have occurred if there had been further discussions between the parties involved.

The Australian Democrats would like to make two other points about why we oppose this Ordinance; one is of a more general nature and the other of a specific nature. We are extremely concerned about all ordinances governing the Australian Capital Territory. We believe far more consultation should take place with the members of the House of Assembly on all ordinances affecting the Australian Capital Territory. After all, in a democratic society it is the responsibility of those people who are elected to have points of view on matters affecting the people who have elected them. The legislation governing the establishment of the House of Assembly specifically makes the point that the members would be the main democratic reference point for the Minister for the Capital Territory. We believe on this highly sensitive issue the members of the House of Assembly, as the democratically elected representatives of the people of the Australian Capital Territory, ought to have been consulted. The members of the House of Assembly above all are the people who could be presumed to be able to speak for the people of the Australian Capital Territory and not for one particular group in the Australian Capital Territory. I believe time and again ordinances have been brought forward by the Minister without reference to the House of Assembly which have been discovered in fact to run against the views and wishes of the people of the Australian Capital Territory. I am speaking of a democratic principle. I do not worry about whether the House of Assembly in the Australian Capital Territory has a majority of Labor members, Liberals or Democrats. The democratic principle remains the same. The members of the House of Assembly are the people who have been elected by the people of the Australian Capital Territory and those members deserve the democratic consideration of consultation. I believe if they had been consulted in this instance we would not have had this Ordinance.

The specific point I wish to make is that the Government itself in various statements does not seem to have any major argument against the removal of this Ordinance and indeed it has suggested it will be bringing forward a new general ordinance before Anzac Day next year. If that is so there is no reason why the Senate ought to allow an ordinance which is going to be changed and with which it does not agree. The Government itself does not agree with this Ordinance. It wishes to change it. This would seem to be an appropriate time for the Senate to express under the regulations governing ordinances that it is of the view that this Ordinance ought not to remain on the books as it has failed in its purpose. It has introduced a discordant note into what is a very important event for all Australians. I believe, in areas such as this, minority viewpoints must not be crushed by the majority. It is a very delicate matter as to how we balance the problems of minority and majority viewpoints.

As this Ordinance relates to Anzac Day I make this final point. I do not believe there is anybody in this chamber who would doubt that the people who fought and died for Australia, the people who are commemorated on that day, must have questioned when they were in battle or when they were called upon to die whether it was worth while making such a sacrifice. I am sure that they did wonder whether the society they were dying for was worth the effort. I am sure they must have done that. If that was so I believe they placed an additional obligation on us as legislators to make sure that no law goes forward which in any way can be said to make this society a worse place. I believe this regulation does make it a worse place.

The Australian Labor Party is to be commended for bringing this matter forward. I believe the Government itself has already suggested it wishes to dispense with such an ordinance. The Australian Democrats agree with both views and believe the Senate ought to support the disallowance of this regulation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, because I have spoken on three occasions already on this subject which relates to the disallowance of the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance-on 28 April, 14 May and on 5 June-and also because of the way in which Senator Ryan and Senator Macklin have dealt with the issue tonight I certainly do not propose to go over the whole of the grounds again. If I speak not only with more brevity on this occasion but also with less passion than in the past it is not because I feel any less warmly on this subject but rather because of the obviously debilitated condition of my voice.

SPEECH.PARA: The basic points, however, that I think need to be made, in some cases recapitulated, which are relevant both to the merits of this Ordinance and to the separate question of what we should now do with the Ordinance are these: In the first place, the Traffic (Amendment) Ordinance of 1981 was promulgated in circumstances which can only be described as those of great and undignified haste on 23 April, just two days before last Anzac Day. The Ordinance, having been thus promulgated, was announced by an unholy trinity of Ministers-Messrs Durack, Newman and Hodgman-that day, without there having been any consultation with the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly as had been consistently recommended, most recently in the 64th report by the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and without of course there having been any opportunity for the Ordinance to be subject to the consideration and ultimately disallowance procedures of the chamber. The promulgation of this Ordinance was based, it seems, on the anticipated offensive disturbance of the last Anzac Day procession by some monstrous regiment of boiler-suited Marxist lesbians and, moreover, on the legal belief, which was quite unfounded, that the existing law was not adequate to deal with this awful anticipated situation.

The legal assumption that the existing law was inadequate to deal with any such disturbance was quite unfounded; so, too, proved to be the factual assumption. It proved to be quite unfounded in practice because the demonstration, such as it was, was peaceful and dignified. It was not calculated to offend and was not likely to offend the sensibilities of anyone except the most choleric, chauvinist, narrow-minded Returned Services League blimp. The facts, such as they were and such as they worked themselves out on Anzac Day, did not stop the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, shooting off his mouth, as Senator Ryan has said, in defence of both the terms of the Ordinance and the 64 arrests that were made under it. He did so on the following Monday, 27 April, in the Canberra Times and on the Australian Broadcasting Commission radio program AM. The Minister did so in a manner which seems to me to have been inaccurate and offensive and which would probably have constituted a contempt of court, calculated to prejudice unfairly the proceedings then pending against the persons arrested and charged. I have raised this matter with the Attorney-General and asked him what, if any, action he proposes to take in relation to Mr Hodgman's performance in this respect.

The next point to come to is the terms of the Ordinance, which are and remain manifestly objectionable. They are provisions which manifestly trespass unduly on the rights and liberties of the subject within the terms of the criteria supposed to be applied by the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. They are equally obvious terms which offend even the most relaxed interpretation of the application of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights to which, in emasculated form, Australia is now a party. It is sheer casuistry for Senator Lewis to claim, as he did tonight, that the Regulations and Ordinances Committee made no explicit findings, when it reported to the Senate, that there had been a breach of that Committee's guidelines. The whole thrust of the report, such as it was, which was brought forward to the Senate was that there was no need, in the view of the Committee, to deal with the Ordinance because it would be dealt with anyway. It was to be subsumed in some larger ordinance dealing more appropriately, in some better way, with all processions and demonstrations that take place in the Australian Capital Territory and not singling out the Anzac Day one.

Senator Missen is trying to intrude into this debate, interestingly, only from the comfort of his seat. I have no doubt that his conscience is afflicting him to such an extent that we will not hear from him tonight. Are Senator Missen and those members of the Committee who joined him in this report really claiming that the only thing wrong with the Anzac Day Ordinance is that its terms do not extend to every other kind of procession and demonstration that is held in the Australian Capital Territory? Is that what is wrong with it-that it is really a pretty good Ordinance but it is not far-reaching enough? Of course that is not what he is saying. He is shaking his head because he knows as well as I do that it is a rotten Ordinance in the form in which it is presently drafted; it is over broad, it is vague and it does intrude on the rights and liberties of individual subjects. Senator Missen made it clear implicitly, if not explicitly, in what he had to say on 14 May. Senator Tate made it clear. Senator Cavanagh, whom Senator Lewis quoted very selectively indeed, made it quite clear when he said on page 2047 of Hansard-the page Senator Lewis quoted but further down-the following:

We have looked at the Ordinance to see whether it complies with out regulations. The question has arisen as to whether the Ordinance is in breach of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. I consider that it is. It is our responsibility to point that out, and we are doing so.

Senator Cavanagh, not speaking just for himself but speaking obviously on behalf of the Committee, encaptured in a sentence what was clearly the substance of the Committee's reaction. Both he and Senator Tate quite explicitly suggested that it would be inappropriate for the prosecutions to proceed under the circumstances and made explicit recommendations to this effect. Senator Lewis very carefully hedged his remarks and said nothing which could be construed as criticism of the Ordinance, no doubt because with the attitude of Senator Lewis, which we all know about, he undoubtedly manifestly approved of all its terms. Be that as it may, it is clear to my mind-it emerges from the correspondence and what was said in the Parliament-that the Committee made the only finding it could make; that is, even if not expressing it in formal terms, that this was an unsatisfactory Ordinance-it would not have jurisidiction to report at all were this not so-because, on the face of it, it did offend against the terms of the Committee's jurisdiction.

The reasons for such a reaction, which has been a very widespread one and which does seem to have been acknowledged by the Minister himself, are not hard to find when one looks at the terms of the Ordinance itself. I do not want to repeat the lengthy evaluation of the language of the Ordinance which I gave on a previous occasion. I just want to say one or two things about the most striking aspects of that language. It goes way beyond existing public order law and any existing reasonable regulation of public order law in its prohibition of peaceful expressions of political or moral opinion. I say that it goes beyond any reasonable regulation of these things by virtue of a number of provisions but no one more obviously than that provision in the Ordinance which multiplies subjective discretion upon subjective discretion and penalises behaviour which is in fact at several removes from anything that could be described as behaviour which is offensive to any reasonable objective person concerned, as we all undoubtedly are, to maintain the dignity of occasions such as Anzac Day.

It is possible under this Ordinance, as the language stands at the moment, to be convicted and fined for an offence if one ignores the direction of a police officer made in circumstances in which a police officer gives a direction believing that it is likely that the person in question will in turn be likely to engage in conduct which in turn is likely to cause offence to some person participating in the parade. So there are three degrees of mere likelihood that have to be satisfied, but this offence can still bite under those circumstances. Of course, the kind of offence that has to be likely to be caused is an offence calculated on a purely subjective scale. There is no objective measure of what a reasonably robust citizen might think offensive. It is enough for these provisions of the Ordinance to bite that any person participating in that Anzac Day parade would in fact be offended even by a quiet and dignified laying of a wreath on a war memorial in remembrance, on that solemn occasion, of those women who have suffered, across the centuries and through the generations of warfare, from the ravages of war. If anyone is chauvinist or insensitive enough to be offended by that kind of thing, it is enough to get the offence running.

The Ordinance is bad enough on its own specific terms in this respect but it becomes even worse when one contemplates the extension in the range of that Ordinance which follows from the operation of the inchoate offences which are available elsewhere under Australian Capital Territory law. I am talking about the general law which makes it possible for someone to be charged and convicted of the offence of attempting to commit an offence which is illegal somewhere else. The police in the Australian Capital Territory have experienced some difficulties in persuading magistrates that persons ought to be convicted under this Ordinance. They have had some difficulty in establishing evidence. They have now taken to charging people with attempting to breach the Australian Capital Territory Ordinance. We now have a situation where people are being brought before the courts, are being charged and, it seems, are being convicted for the offence of attempting to join a demonstration in defiance of a police direction which is, in turn, based on the policeman's subjective assessment of the likelihood of that particular person offending, subjectively, someone else. It is monstrous for people to be subjected to conviction, with all the obloquy that goes with a conviction recorded against them, particularly when it is a conviction for disrupting-which is the way people interpret it-something as solemn, as crucial and as central to the Australian consciousness as Anzac Day. It is outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —They worked that out on the ASIO Bill. That is where it all started.

—Indeed. It is symptomatic of the mentality that produces legislation of this kind. That is the situation. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee was confronted with an intolerable ordinance. It was confronted with the fact also of arrests and prosecutions being made under it, but it had to consider what recommendation it would make.
—You attack that recommendation?

—I do, for the reasons I will now make clear. The recommendations that the Committee brought back into this chamber must rank among the most timid, gutless and disappointing set of recommendations, set of reactions, that the honourable senator opposite or anyone else on that Committee has ever had the temerity to bring forward. Having noticed that whatever the fate of this Ordinance, persons still technically could be prosecuted under it because the disallowance whenever it occurred would not operate retrospectively, having noticed that the Minister had given his undertaking to get the public law ultimately into shape with a subsequent enactment of a general ordinance and having further noticed that this undertaking was to bring forward such a general ordinance before Anzac Day 1982, giving no further occasion then for the operation of the present Ordinance, the Committee decided to settle for that, as sufficient to discharge its particular obligation. It reported that it would take no further action. In doing so, of course, it did nothing that would embarrass the present Minister, Mr Hodgman. A more worthy case for embarrassment, as I have indicated, I cannot think of. Nonetheless, the Committee gutlessly, timidly, took that particular line.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee report contained no recommendation even that the Executive exercise its undoubted powers, its undoubted discretions, to withdraw those prosecutions already launched. As I have indicated, two Labor members of the Committee clearly indicated in this chamber their view that that should happen. The Committee allowed by its report, by its recommendations, to remain on the books with all the credibility that that entails as to the quality of that Ordinance, an ordinance which was manifestly over-broad, manifestly insensitive and manifestly offensive to all the criteria with which the Committee had to deal. I find that an intolerable situation and I hope that the Senate finds likewise.

I wish to go quite simply and quickly through the remaining points I want to make. No doubt those of us who favour this disallowance will be asked what use there is in disallowing an ordinance at this stage since we cannot, technically speaking, remove the basis for the present prosecutions because the law will always remain as it was at the time that the arrests were made. Nonetheless, I support the disallowance of this Ordinance and I hope that the Senate will, too, for the reasons I will now give. First, the disallowance will amount to a clear and unequivocal statement to the Executive that the legislature regards this Ordinance as being indefensible and unjustified. The action of the Senate in doing this tonight should encourage the Executive, as nothing else seems to have, to direct the withdrawal of those particular prosecutions. Secondly, the disallowance will amount to a clear indication to the courts by this Parliament, in the unhappy event that matters do still come before the courts, that it does not believe that this Ordinance ever should have become law. It will amount to an indication to the courts as to the attitude of the most representative assembly in this nation, that this is an unhappy, unattractive law that should not remain on the books. As such, that cannot influence whether or not the courts will in fact find themselves obliged to record a conviction in this case but undoubtedly it will have some impact on the penalty under those particular circumstances which the courts will be minded to apply.

Thirdly, disallowance of the Ordinance tonight will be a clear demonstration to the Australian community that this Parliament does in fact care about civil liberties, that it does in fact care about protecting the right of peaceful political expression. The absence of a willingness to disallow this Ordinance can be construed only as a profound indifference to the worth that that right should enjoy in the pantheon of Australian values. That is an unhappy state of affairs. Maybe the final point will appeal even to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), who is home in his sick bed. Many people are following rather closely Australia's domestic attitude to human rights. The disallowance of this particular Ordinance will be a demonstration internationally-that is not unimportant in the context of forthcoming international events in this country-that we are not prepared to tolerate manifest infringements of individual liberty and manifest interferences with freedom of expression by vague and over-broad statutory language of this kind. For all those reasons I support the disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an interesting, if historical debate tonight. At that time he was not satisfied with the unanimous recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. At that time he tried to silence his colleague Senator Tate. He was very angry at the opinions which were expressed and the decisions made by Senator Cavanagh, the Deputy Chairman of the Committee who was a Labor member of long standing and who was held in great respect in that Committee. Senator Evans disagreed with the view of Senator Cavanagh and Senator Tate that there should not be a motion for disallowance of this Ordinance. He was very angry at that time. —It is a part of it.

—Oh, it is only a part of it. After all the honourable senator has said against the Senate over the years-he has had a lot to say against it both before and after he came here-at least it is a part of the most representative institution in this nation. —It has not happened yet. It may never happen.

—The honourable senator is one of little faith. The honourable senator believes it will never happen. Ye of little faith. I have been speaking in the corridors of power tonight to the Minister. He assures me that it has been drafted and that it will come along.
—You cannot take any notice of Hodgman. He will tell you anything. He would tell you that the sun will rise in the west tomorrow and you would believe him.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister points out in support of his proposal that attention was drawn to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights ratified by Australia on 13 August 1980, article 21 of which expressly refers to the recognition of the right of peaceful assembly. SPEECH.PARA: One would almost think that the Opposition did not want to see this ordinance. I remind the Opposition of an article which was written not very long ago, in April 1981, by Mr Robin Handley. It is entitled 'Assembly Laws and Civil Rights Covenant' and appeared in the Legal Service Bulletin. Let me remind the Senate first that article 21 of the Covenant states:

The right of peaceful assembly shall be recognised. No restrictions may be placed on the exercise of this right other than those imposed in conformity with the law and which are necessary in a democratic society in the interests of national security or public safety, public order, the protection of public health or morals or the protection of the rights and freedoms of others.
This article was written, of course, before this ordinance came about, and I think it is indicative of what is a sensible attitude towards this situation. Mr Handley states:

Given its obligations under the International Covenant discussed above, the Federal Government should now initiate a reform of the law of assembly in the ACT, so that the right of assembly expressed in Article 21 is given legal recognition, and an effective remedy for violation of that right is provided in accordance with article 2, para. 3.

DEBATE.TITLE: SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1-9) 1981SALES TAX AMENDMENT BILLS (Nos 1A-9A) 1981SALES TAX (EXEMPTIONS AND CLASSIFICATIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 August, on motion by Senator Peter Baume:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bills being debated divide into three groups. One group, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1 to 9) 1981, increase by 2 1/2 per cent the tax paid on goods already subject to sales tax. Those Bills became operative on 19 August. Another group, the Sales Tax Amendment Bills (Nos 1A to 9A) 1981, levy a tax of 2 1/2 per cent on a wide range of goods previously exempt from tax. That legislation is due to become operative on 1 January 1982. The other Bill amends the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act and will impose either higher or new taxes on 29 items and lower taxes on five items. The Government claims that that Bill's purpose is to correct anomalies. The extra $142m tax levied by it is, according to the Government, quite incidental.

SPEECH.PARA: These Bills are inflationary, unjust and unnecessary. They are a flagrant breach of a multiplicity of Government pre-election and post-election promises not to move towards a broad-based consumption tax. The Australian Labor Party will vote against all of the Bills at the second reading stage, as we did in the House of Representatives. We sincerely hope that Senator Harradine and the Australian Democrats will join us in ensuring that the Bills are defeated.

TALK.START.PARA: —You haven't heard our case. Yours is a very democratic party!

—The mice are squealing. If that does not happen, several options will be considered by the Labor Party during the Committee stage with a view to mitigating the damage and injustice which these Bills will inflict. Some options in this respect have been suggested by Senator Harradine and by the Australian Democrats. At this stage we have a number of reservations and qualifications about Senator Harradine's ingenious proposal and about what we understand to be the Democrats' present position. But we will certainly give further close attention to all these matters before the Committee stage of the debate.

SPEECH.PARA: On 19 August, on the morning after these Bills were introduced, Bill Hayden announced that the Labor Party would oppose them. From the outset there has been no prevarication and no obfuscation by the ALP. There has been some woolly minded and ill-informed criticism of that decision, the epitomy of which is the ridiculous assertion by Senator Carrick, amongst others, that Labor is trying to reject Supply. There are several clear and qualitative distinctions between rejecting these Bills and rejecting Supply or Appropriation Bills. The most obvious is that Appropriation Bills spend money whereas these Bills seek to raise it. Rejecting Appropriation Bills prevents a government from paying pensions or wages to its employees. Rejecting the present Bills does not. Indeed, the only consequence of rejecting these Bills would be to reduce the Budget domestic surplus to around $1,000m from the estimated $1,500m. The Government does not even need the money which these Bills seek to raise.

On more than a dozen occasions in the last Parliament Labor opposed and voted against taxation measures in the Senate. The most significant Bills consistently opposed have been those which are now slugging Australian motorists for more than $3 billion a year. The first of these import parity oil pricing Bills was part of the 1978 Budget package. All subsequent Budgets have contained similar Bills and all were opposed by Labor. I note that even Senator Mason voted with Labor in an attempt to reject the brandy excise increase which was part of the 1978 Budget.

The distinction between a Budget tax measure and a non-Budget tax measure is specious. There is no qualitative difference between money from one source and money from another. I will expand on this point later. It is correct that no tax measures were actually rejected in the last Parliament. That, however, has not always been the case. A close analogy to the rejection of these Bills is not the blocking of the Appropriation Bills in 1975 but rejection of the Medibank levy in 1974. The Medibank analogy is not perfect. The Senate of 1974 rejected a component of the Medibank program on which Labor had just fought and won the double dissolution election. That action stopped the Labour Government from doing what it had explicitly stated for two years it would do. Rejecting these Bills, on the other hand, would stop the Fraser Government from doing what it has explicitly stated for two years it would not do; that is, move towards a broad-based consumption tax. At no stage has the Labor Party, or to my knowledge anyone else, suggested that rejecting the Medibank levy was tantamount to rejecting Supply. I have nothing but contempt for Liberal-National Country Party hypocrites who assert their permanent right to reject Appropriation Bills whenever they please and the Labor Party's permanent obligation never to do so.

If I may observe somewhat parenthetically, in discussions about Appropriation Bills it is usually assumed that a rejection of an Appropriation Bill would inevitably lead to a repeat of the events of 1975. I want to lodge one caveat to that. Because a drunken vice-regal megalomaniac, supported by a chief justice conspicuous for facilitating tax dodging and forging company documents-obliged the political right by sacking a Labor government in 1975, it does not necessarily mean that all Governors-General would do the same. In particular, I doubt whether the incumbent, who was once noted as a mealy-mouthed apologist for our intervention in Vietnam, would sack a conservative government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think those words are uncalled for and I suggest that you regard them as out of order. I ask, through you, that Senator Walsh moderate his language because I find it offensive.
—If you find it offensive, Senator Jessop, and you ask for a withdrawal, I will ask Senator Walsh to withdraw.
—I ask that he withdraw the term 'mealy-mouthed' and other such terms that he used. It is disrespectful.

—If Senator Jessop finds the words offensive, Mr Deputy President, I am quite willing to withdraw them. I doubt, however, whether the incumbent Governor-General would sack a conservative government under the same circumstances. What any future Governor-General might do in similar circumstances remains a matter for speculation. I move now to the Bills. The first point to be noted is that they repudiate a number of pre-election and post-election undertakings. They repudiate specifically in context the assurance that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) gave when he made a major statement in the House on 12 March. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: Throughout its consideration of this issue, the Government remained firmly of the view that if a shift towards greater emphasis on indirect taxation were to occur, it should be accompanied by a noticeable reduction in personal income tax.

That statement was made in the context of a Government denial of any intent to move towards a broadly based consumption tax. The Government has welched not only on that undertaking, but also on the condition attached to any such possible move by the Treasurer at the time. This vary substantial increase in indirect tax revenue and this broadening of the indirect tax base are accompanied, not by a reduction in income tax, but by a massive 22 per cent increase in income tax paid by wage and salary earners and a slightly lower increase in income tax overall.

The Bills are unnecessary. They are inflationary and they are unjust. It seems extraordinary that, at a time when the unemployment rate remains at 5.5 per cent and is, according to the Government's own forecasts, going to go higher this financial year, a government should budget for a domestic surplus in excess of $1.5 billion, a surplus to which these measures will contribute about one-third. Pre-Keynesian primitivism is on the rampage. That extraordinary decision is, of course, based on the Stone Age belief that a contractionary Budget-one which slows down or stops economic growth-will automatically reduce the inflation rate. In some mystical way that has not yet been explained, that belief is reconciled with a forecast in the same Budget Papers that in fact the inflation rate will rise. Indeed, the actual expectation of the Treasury is that it will rise by a good deal more than the 10.75 per cent forecast in the Budget. This is another manifestation of the extraordinary Fraser Government policy of beating inflation through putting up prices. The Budget Papers admit that, as a direct consequence of these Bills, the consumer price index will increase by 0.75 per cent. It ought to be noted that there is a significant degree of statistical trickery underlying that figure. The 0.75 per cent figure quoted is the average increase in prices for this financial year over the average level of prices in the last financial year which can be attributed to the sales tax measures. The more conventional way of measuring the effect of a particular component of inflation is to compare the figures for the June quarters-in this case June 1982 and June 1981. On that basis, these Bills will add 1.1 per cent to the consumer price index. I refer those who doubt that calculation to the fact that in a full year the measures are predicted to raise $892m in revenue and that total expenditure on items contained within the CPI regimen is approximately $80 billion. The former is 1.1 per cent of the latter. That the sales tax Bills are unjust, because like virtually all indirect taxes they have a regressive impact on the distribution of income, is so self-evident that it needs no further elaboration.

As I said earlier, there has been no prevarication by the Labor Party on this issue. The morning after the Budget the party leader announced that Labor would oppose these Bills. We have never wavered from that decision. The position of the Australian Democrats has been somewhat different. I think its dilemma is very largely a function of original mutually exclusive promises to 'keep the bastards honest' and yet not reject money Bills, which, if a government introduced any money or taxation Bill which breached a pre-election undertaking, obviously left its members in the position where they could not honour both undertakings. Senator Chipp sought to explain away the problem on the PM program of 19 August when he said:

And this proposal of the Labor Party, which unfortunately is knee jerk, I think it hasn't been considered, the implications of it, would take $811m away from consolidated revenue in the rest of the year.
I interpolate-I am not accusing Senator Chipp of having done this deliberately-that the correct figure in that context is $550m, not $811m. He continued:
Now, I would have thought, and I don't often agree with Mr Fraser, that a government in that situation would find itself it couldn't govern and would regard it virtually as having Supply blocked.

Two hours later Senator Haines introduced into the Senate a private member's Bill which sought to exempt from taxable income the first $1,000 of interest payments on deposits with building societies and savings banks. She was questioned eight days later on the estimated cost should this Bill be enacted. She was asked, firstly, whether she had an estimate of the cost; secondly, whether that estimate was compatible with another estimate putting the cost at $900m; and, thirdly, whether any measure which reduced government revenue to anything like that extent would constitute messing around with the Budget. She answered two of the three questions on the spot. Firstly, she said that she did not have any idea of what the cost would be; that it had not been costed. She also answered the last question, saying that it would not comprise messing around with the Budget because the Democrats would pursue this proposal through a legislative procedure outside the Budget Bills. I will say a bit more about that later. Later that day she presented to the Senate an estimate of the cost of her Bill, should it become law, of around $800m a year, which was roughly compatible with the $900m figure which had been obtained from another source.

The point I want to take up here is that it is utterly specious to assert that there is any qualitative difference between a Bill which reduces government revenue and which is associated with the Budget and a Bill which reduces government revenue and which is not associated with the Budget. There is absolutely no qualitative difference. The only relevant factor is the amount of money involved. This Budget contains estimates of revenue from sales taxes and from income taxes. In both cases certain assumptions are built into those estimates-the assumption that these Bills will be passed by the Senate and the assumption that no other amendments to the income tax legislation other than those proposed by the Government will be made. Rejecting the sales tax Bills-the position to which the Labor Party is committed-erodes the sales tax base and to some extent the sales tax rate. The Bill of Senator Haines would erode the income tax base. The cost to revenue of both is near identical and in every other way they should be regarded as identical. To say that there is a qualitative difference because one seeks to amend other legislation which was announced by the Budget and the other just seeks to amend long-standing provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act is utterly specious.

The strategy of the members of the Australian Democrats in pursuing what they now say to be their objective is equally confused. As I understand it, the members of the Australian Democrats have stated that they propose to tack on requests during the Committee stage of these Bills. They will request that the House of Representatives amend the Bills to delete some of the categories of goods which will be subject to tax if these Bills are passed. In the most extraordinary display of naivety-to take a charitable view-the Democrats have also stated that if the House of Representatives does not accept those requests it will not press its opposition in the Senate to the point of voting against the Bills. In other words, an open-ended invitation has been extended to the Government to treat with contempt the action the Democrats propose to take in the Senate. I observe again in passing that that is no way to keep the bastards honest. However, it may well be that that is not the Democrats' plan at all. In the Sydney Morning Herald of 28 August this matter appears to have been raised by Paul Kelly in an interview with Senator Mason who was then the Acting Leader of the Democrats. Kelly wrote:

Senator Mason said it was possible that 'further options' would be put to the Australian Democratic Senators that would involve outright rejection of some of the Government's sales tax extensions to basic items such as clothing, footwear and building materials.
What follows is in direct quotes. The article continues:
'We remain interested in trying to put teeth into our objection to the unjust aspects of the sales tax rises,' Senator Mason said.
Asked if the party would consider rejection of some sales tax rises, Senator Mason said: 'I would regard this as an option and I would propose that we consider it.'

As far as I know there has been no statement, no claim, by the Australian Democrats that Kelly and the Sydney Morning Herald have misrepresented or misreported its position. This leaves the rest of us in the very confused position of not knowing whether to take seriously what Senator Mason has said on behalf of the Democrats on that occasion or whether to take seriously what has been said by several spokesmen for the Australian Democrats on other occasions. Perhaps Senator Mason will clarify this later in the debate on the second reading.

It seems to me that the real problem the Australian Democrats face apart from the mutually exclusive promises they had originally given was that when Bill Hayden came out on the morning of 19 August with a very forthright statement that the Australian Labor Party would oppose these Bills, the members of the Australian Democrats did not know quite what to do. They had become accustomed for some time before that to having the limelight and they thought the way to regain the limelight was to adopt what they claim to believe is a high moral position. It is now very clear that if that was their strategy they miscalculated.

I will make a couple of other observations about the fiscal consequences of the Supply Bills and the conventional wisdom that they are an integral part of the 1983 election strategy of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and the Liberal Party. The conventional wisdom is that because of the additional revenue raised from these Bills and because they have greatly broadened the sales tax base relatively small percentage increases in sales tax will in the future yield much larger increases in revenue than has been the case in the past and that Mr Fraser is putting away a nest egg which will fund tax cuts in the 1983 Budget prior to the election. That is a reasonable paraphrase of the conventional wisdom. I have no doubt that there is some truth in that hypothesis. I will say a little more about that later.

I suggest that what is more important and what has not been said very often concerns what Mr Fraser used to call the secret tax of inflation and what economists call fiscal drag. That is the fact that with unchanged tax schedules and rising money incomes not only does the amount of taxation increase but also the proportion of income paid in tax increases. With money incomes increasing at their present rate that phenomenon which economists call fiscal drag and which the Prime Minister used to call the secret tax of inflation-I have not noticed him calling it that lately-increases real income tax by around $1.5 billion a year. This is not just the money increase in income tax but the real increase in income tax of around $1,500m a year. This is while money incomes continue to rise at present levels and the tax schedules and thresholds remain unindexed. By 1983 there will be a real-not just illusory-$3 billion surplus of potential revenue lying around that the Prime Minister will be able to very generously lop off personal income tax collections and call a tax cut.

Some of the more gullible members of the community, and possibly of the Press, will accept it as being a tax cut. In fact if that should happen of course it will not be a tax cut but merely a reversion to the real level of taxation which applied in the financial year 1980-81. This will be marketed as a tax cut. Notwithstanding that enormous potential which the Prime Minister will have in 1983 to offer of what are, in fact, illusionary tax cuts resulting from fiscal drag-which he used to call the secret tax of inflation-I believe there is some truth in the hypothesis that the Prime Minister identified the substantial broadening of the sales tax base and increasing sales tax rates as something which will supplement and add to the potential to offer fraudulent tax cuts in 1983. The reason I say that is because the whole proposition bears the mark of yet another half-smart, half-shonkey political stunt which came straight off the top of the Prime Minister's head and is comparable to the film tax haven rort which will cost revenue 120 per cent of the cost of making every film that qualifies for the concession. There is also the water conservation and reticulation rort which will cost revenue up to 105 per cent of the money invested in that area and a number of other taxation rorts which include the fuel tank storage rort which the Prime Minister pulled out of the hat prior to the last election.

I suspect that these measures were inserted in the Budget very close to its presentation even within the last fortnight. As a result of that there is widespread confusion. The Treasurer glibly said in Perth 11 days ago that if anyone had a query about the application and administration of these new taxes he should ring the Australian Taxation Office. The plain fact is that the taxation officers in Perth and, as far as I know everywhere else, cannot answer those questions. They cannot answer those questions because the bureaucracy at its highest levels has not circulated explanatory memoranda to its branches. I am not blaming the bureaucracy for that. The Government has massively complicated the administration of sales tax evidently without making any more staff available to do it and certainly, without its briefing its own officers on how the changes are to be administered. In the Treasurer's Budget Speech he glibly said:
The Government has decided to increase by 2 1/2 per cent each of the existing rates of sales tax, effective in relation to goods passing the taxing point after tonight.

Firms which have both wholesale and retail operations on the same premises are by no means unusual. I refer to firms which handle automotive parts and accessories-a number of building suppliers, for example. In their case, how will the taxing point, to use the Treasurer's phrase, be identified unless a stocktaking is conducted on Budget night or the day after the Budget is brought down? If a stocktaking is required, and I fail to see how anything other than a stocktaking can satisfactorily resolve the question, have any of these wholesaler-retailers operating out of common premises been advised that they will be required to take stock? If not, why not?

Traders in goods which previously were exempt from sales tax but which now are not exempt must register within 28 days under the provisions of the Sales Tax Assessment Act. Under section 13 of that Act, if they do not do so they will be subject to a mandatory fine of $200 for every day that they remain in breach of the Act. A retail butcher who cuts up a bullock's liver in a shop and then sells it as dog's meat apparently will be liable to pay a sales tax of 17 1/2 per cent on the dog's meat because, in the act of cutting up the liver, he has become a manufacturer of pet food. That is just a sample of the sort of anomaly for which the bureaucracy is ill-prepared because the Fraser Government continues to behave in an erratic and irresponsible way. These Bills are ill-prepared and the bureaucracy and the Government are ill-prepared to administer them. They are unnecessary. Moreover, they will damage the economy in its present state. They are undoubtedly very inflationary. They will have a significantly greater effect on inflation than the Government has formally admitted and they are unjust. For all of these reasons, I sincerely trust that the Australian Democrats, Senator Harradine and even-I say it without much hope-some Liberal or National Country Party members on the other side of the chamber will give these Bills the treatment they deserve and throw them out of the second reading stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately the Sales Tax Amendment Bills. At the outset I observe that a sales tax is a tax on consumption. Unlike income tax it taxes that which is taken from production rather than from a worker's personal contribution to production. Therefore, it encourages saving by discouraging expenditure. Thus a sales tax is one means of encouraging investment and thereby increasing future consumption and rates of growth. The move towards a greater reliance on sales tax is part of the process of reducing tax avoidance and tax evasion. It is much more difficult to avoid paying a turnover tax than it is to get out of paying one's income tax.
—Sydney to Melbourne via London.

—I would prefer that honourable members opposite remain silent while I try to make my point. The proposed sales taxes are part of the process of balancing the Budget. The higher sales tax rates will produce an estimated additional $800m in revenue during 1981-82. As revenues from the oil levy begin to diminish, this source of revenue may become more important.
