TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. This comparison of indirect taxation derived by various countries is quite significant. To illustrate briefly, I point out that France derives 23.7 per cent of its tax revenue from consumption taxes and that Australia, at the bottom end of the scale, derives only 6.7 per cent from that source. The impetus for introducing a general indirect tax at this time is the prospect that the tax revenue currently provided by the oil levy will soon begin to diminish. The excise on oil and liquefied petroleum gas made up 8.3 per cent of tax revenue in 1979-80 and is expected to account for 9.9 per cent during 1980-81. As revenue from this source declines, other sources of revenue will have to be found. The alternatives facing the Government are to raise revenue either through a broadly based indirect tax, or by means of an even greater reliance on present sources of tax revenue, in particular personal and corporate income taxes.
—They will be reduced.

—The object of the exercise is to consider that. The income tax option is, less favoured by the Government for the reason that Senator Townley's interjection implies-firstly, its negative impact on incentives to produce and earn income and, secondly, the current level of income tax avoidance and evasion. If there is to be a greater reliance on indirect taxes, it will be necessary to find the tax that is best suited to Australia's political and economic framework. The main requirements for such a tax are that it should raise the required revenue, should be administratively simple and cheap, should keep the economic side effects to a minimum and should be politically acceptable. On the whole, sales tax fits this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make it clear at the outset that I am not opposed to the principle of indirect taxation through sales tax, that in fact I believe it to be a legitimate avenue for governments to raise revenue. What I am opposed to, and concerned about, is the advice which has been provided to the Government on these latest sales tax increases. One obviously assumes that the Treasury, and perhaps the Department of Business and Consumer Affairs and the Department of Industry and Commerce, have competence to examine a proposal, to weigh its pros and cons and then decide whether to recommend that the Government proceed with it. Such departments are supposedly staffed with highly trained experts in the industry policy field. On such assumptions governments take decisions and perform efficiently and smoothly, or so they should. However, it is an assumtion. At times examples arise in which the credibility of such advice is called into question when as a result of a policy option being adopted confusion and dislocation occur. I believe the confusion and dislocation caused by the announcement of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) of increased sales taxes is such an example. It appears to throw doubt upon the apparent research carried out by the departments concerned into the flow on effects of such increases.

One can easily point to another example of the same thing. We all remember vividly the drastic effects upon the economy and employment of the 25 per cent across-the-board tariff reduction which was introduced by the Whitlam Government. Once again one imagines that such a decision did not come about without departmental study of the consequences. Governments must ensure that the situations do not arise. It must be recognised that policies which have the potential to affect wide sections of the business community must be thoroughly detailed and researched to ensure that any changes resulting are carried out smoothly. It must be recognised that policies affecting wide sections of the business community cannot be formulated on generalised grounds. Recognition must be given to the differing effects upon different businesses and industries and the fact that certain sectors of the economy cannot respond to changes overnight. Industry in Australia is too complex for this to take place. In other words, policies must not be adopted indiscriminately. Discrimination must be the key word and should have been the key word in relation to the present sales tax increases.

Since the Treasurer's announcement last month of the increases I-and I imagine this applies to many of my colleagues-have been inundated with letters and phone calls drawing my attention to areas in which problems have arisen. One of the first to approach me was a pharmaceutical wholesaler in Adelaide. He informed me of the situation which had arisen there whereby some retailers had stated that they would not process invoices that contained the increases until the legislation was passed. This left the wholesaler in a Catch 22 situation; either he charged the new price and was forced to wait a month or more for payment, thus jeopardising his cashflow, or did not add the new rates and on the advice he had at the time would be penalised by the Taxation Office. Further, this wholesaler related how, on his own initiative, he contacted the Taxation Office in Adelaide on Wednesday 19 August to seek information on what products were affected by the new rates. He was informed that such information was not available and it was not known when it would be available. Clearly, this indicates a lack of preparedness on the part of the Taxation Office which in itself caused much confusion to the business community. After taking this matter up with the Treasurer, the Treasurer provided me with a reply which I have shown to the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button). The Treasurer wrote this letter in response to the questions that faced the pharmaceutical wholesaler. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.
Treasurer Parliament House Canberra 2600 26 August 1981 Senator D. S. Jessop

Dear Senator Jessop I have looked into the matters raised with you by Mr . . ., a pharmaceutical wholesaler, of Goodwood, South Australia, concerning the sales tax increases which I announced in the Budget Speech.

In the first place I feel that I must emphasise that the sales tax legislation has been, in much the same basic format as it is in today, in operation for more than 50 years. Traditionally, since its introduction in 1930 changes in rates of sales tax have been effected by amending Bills which, when they are passed by Parliament and receive the Royal Assent, operate on and after the day following their introduction into the House of Representatives. Increases in rates of sales tax have never operated retrospectively.

This has been done deliberately so that market forces operate as normally as possible both before and after an announcement concerning increases and decreases in rates of sales tax. You will appreciate that there would be little chance of market forces operating normally if taxpayers were forewarned of pending increases or decreases in rates of sales tax. You will also appreciate that any forewarning of pending rate changes would undoubtedly adversely affect the revenue.

I would like to draw your attention to the changes in rates of sales tax which have occurred since 1961. It was announced in the 1961 Budget Speech on 15 August 1961 that the then existing sales tax rates would be reduced from 8 1/3% to 2 1/2% in respect of a range of household goods and from 40% to 30% in respect of motor vehicles of the non-commercial type. The new rates operated on and after 16 August 1961. The relevant Bills received the Royal Assent on 27 October 1961.

On 6 February 1962 Bills were introduced which effectively reduced the rates of sales tax on non-commercial motor vehicles from 30 to 22 1/2% and on commercial vehicles from 16 2/3% to 12 1/2%. The new rates operated from 7 February 1962. The Bills received the Royal Assent on 23 March 1962.

For the 1964 Budget Speech on 11 August 1964 it was announced that the rates of sales tax on non-commercial motor vehicles would be increased from 22 1/2% to 25%. The new rate operated on and after 12 August 1964. The relevant Bills received the Royal Assent on 5 November 1964.

On 13 August 1968, the then Treasurer announced in his Budget Speech that the general rate of sales (then 12 1/2%) was to be increased to 15%. The general rate of sales tax applied then, as it does now, to a very wide range of goods, including sporting equipment, commercial motor vehicles, toys, novelties, etc. The new rate operated on and after 14 August 1968. The relevant Bills received the Royal Assent on 21 November 1968.

Rate changes were also announced in the 1970 Budget Speech on 17 August 1970, operative on and after 18 August 1970, and in the 1978 Budget Speech on 15 August 1978, operative on and after 16 August 1978.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter contains a number of interesting points relating to sales tax generally, and I will mention some of them later. However, on the whole the letter does not address itself in any great detail to the major concern, that is, the Catch 22 situation in which many wholesalers have found themselves. This was only the first indication that I had directly of the confusion and dislocation which was resulting from the Treasurer's announcement. The media carried examples of wider and more national concern about the measure. In an article in the Australian Financial Review of 25 August the Managing Director of Cadbury-Schweppes indicated his concern directly to the Treasurer at a meeting of the Institute of Directors of Australia. In that article Mr Hughes, whose group depends on confectionery and soft drink sales for a massive slice of its revenue, criticised the sudden withdrawal of exemptions from sales tax plus the 2.5 per cent additional increase on consumer items contained in the Budget. The article reported that sales tax on chocolate, confectionery goods and non-returnable containers for soft drinks leapt from zero to 17.5 per cent on Budget day. The article continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Hughes said the 17.5 per cent increase on many items on the retail shelf would have a serious impact on consumer spending and would create a real backlash in terms of sales and company profitability.
'This ripple effect will be very significant', Mr Hughes said. He challenged Mr Howard to nominate a time and place to sit down and discuss the implications for industry of 'the additional burden'.

On 29 August the Australian Financial Review reported that the director-general of the Confederation of Australian Industry had sent a letter to the Treasurer expressing his concern. In that article Mr Henderson is reported to have said:

'The disruption has been exacerbated because the business community, which is charged with the collection of the tax, was given no notice that such a wide-ranging alteration to the sales tax schedules had been decided upon by the Government and were to be suddenly implemented'.
An article in the National Times of 30 August highlighted more of the confusion. It stated:
While the Government said it wanted the proposals exposed to public comment before they were introduced, the changes apply from the date of the announcement.

A yacht charter service, which recently commissioned a new boat at a cost of $1 million, now finds that the boat, nearing completion, is liable for 17.5 per cent sales tax-the builder is seeking to recover $175,000.
Furniture manufacturers have outstanding orders dating back more than three months. In the absence of transition procedures, the contracts will be subjected to the additional tax.

Further examples of this confusion appeared subsequently in other articles in the media. Clearly the example of the Adelaide wholesaler that I cited earlier is not isolated; quite the reverse applies in fact. The effect of the changes is causing widespread dislocation on a national basis and one can only assume that such dislocation is costly to the industries concerned.

Further details of the problems being experienced by business because of the proposed increases was provided to me by the Sydney Sales Tax Discussion Group. This group, consisting of specialists from the sales tax field, and a similar group in Melbourne are unique in Australia. They represent the only people with extensive and detailed knowledge of the legislation and its workings in the sales tax area. I have here a letter which was written to me by a member of that group. I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard. I have shown it to the Leader of the Opposition.

Dear Senator Jessop, I refer to your recent communications with Mr Stephen Bladwell and your Press release of 24 August 1981 in the matter of the sales tax bills presently before Parliament. I make the following comments as a professional advisor in the area of sales tax revenue law.
Many of the businesses with which I am associated in a professional capacity are affected by the proposed retroactive sales tax legislation.

The measures are not consistent with equitable revenue law making principles. They are disruptive to business practice. They cause undue speculation and sharp practice. They are not to be confused with anti-avoidance legislation or income tax legislation. The income tax legislation concerns itself with tax on a measure of gain. The sales tax legislation by contrast is concerned with a tax on the day to day dealings in goods. Depending on the point of view, sales tax may be considered a cost of goods sold or at very least an element of the price of goods. Just as cost structures and price must be taken into account in the day to day transactions of a manufacturer or a wholesale merchant, so the incidence of sales tax must be given consideration.
The situations discussed below indicate the unthinking manner by which the proposed amendments are to be given effect.

To jump through hoops Manufacturers of wholesale merchants with no experience of sales tax who formerly dealt with exempt goods alone are overnight asked to become registered persons for sales tax purposes, familiarise themselves with procedural requirements, re-structure their pricing and make arrangements for the charging of the tax. It is emphasised that all this is required in a time frame which can only be described as instantaneous.

The effect of the proposed amendments of course goes to existing sales tax payers as well as new sales tax payers. Perhaps existing sales tax payers are better able to cope. The distinction is a marginal one of degree only.

Compromise with illegality If taxpayers continue to charge tax at the old rates in the interim period between 19 August 1981 and royal assent, they will have no right of recovery of the additional tax retrospectively imposed. The Commissioner of Taxation will however be entitled to collect tax from those taxpayers at the new rate in respect of sales made in the interim period upon which the old rates of tax have been charged.

Alternatively, the new rates could be charged in the interim period. However, manufacturers and wholesale merchants who do so are in breach of section 70D of Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) with respect to every invoice issued which, in the interim period, shows the new rates of tax which are not law. The penalty prescribed is up to $200 per breach, i.e. per invoice prepared showing the new rates of tax.

Sales tax payers can only preserve their interests by committing those technical breaches. It is little consolation that the retroactive effect of the proposed legislation will ensure that taxpayers will be required to account for tax on those sales at the new rate. It must surely be poor law that requires business people to trade illegally while the revenue law making process is in hand in Parliament.
Actual loss Businesses which for many reasons may not have been able to accommodate the new rates of tax as of 19 August 1981 but are geared to the old rates of tax have two choices.

They either charge tax at the old rate in the certain knowledge that should the bills become law the new rates of tax will be applicable and they will be without right of recovery of the additional tax from their customers. Alternatively, they could suspend all trading operations whilst steps are taken to adjust accounting systems to account for tax at new rates. These new rates of course would not in any case have the force of law.
The penal sanctions applicable to the adoption of the latter procedure have already been mentioned.

Further, actual loss may extend to all manufactures and wholesale merchants selling through dealers to whom retail prices are recommended. Substantial inventories of pre-printed order forms, brochures and other point of sale materials are typically maintained at considerable expense. These materials will be useless unless overprinted or scrapped in favour of replacement.
Consequential loss Section 70A does offer protection for sales tax payers who have agreed a price with a customer which includes an amount of tax which is subsequently increased by change in the law.
It is less than satisfactory to the business community that all firm orders upon which sales tax is incident be subject to arbitrary price changes on account of sales tax.

In markets where price has a strong influence on demand, forward planning may well have been made a nonsense on account of the tax charges where increases in the tax rate or the taxable sale value are substantial.

The protection of Section 70A is thus not a sufficient safeguard in all situations. It is also deficient with regard to collateral contracts. For example, a person in the business of hiring equipment who may have agreed the rentals with a customer on the basis of prices for equipment which are fixed, is afforded no protection under that section.

Financial planning for minor or major acquisitions, or capital works projects is immediately disrupted whenever pre-budget orders mature into post budget sales. Proper consideration to pre-existing orders is, after all, characteristically given under income tax provisions relating to investment allowance or depreciation.

Examples of inequitable impact of budget Even if royal assent were given on 18 August 1981, and the introduction of the legislation thus instantaneous, the following instances would indicate transitional provisions are warranted.

1. A soft drink manufacturer invoices his product with delivery. Deliveries are made daily. Trucks are loaded from a manifest derived from customer orders. The paper work for the whole operation is computer produced on the day prior to delivery and actual sale. Where instantaneous changes to the sales tax legislation occur, such a taxpayer must either suspend sales until the necessary system adjustments are made; depart from all existing procedures and policy and deliver without invoicing; or, invoice product at the old rate of tax until the necessary programming changes are made.

Having adopted the latter course, the company must absorb the tax increase while it fully intends no such result. In the event, the price increases across the range of the company's products amount to 8% to 9% on account of the sales tax. The sales tax component itself has in the case of soft drinks increased by up to 3 times the amount of tax previously payable.

Three days sales were processed at the old rate of tax prior to adjustment to computer programs. Those adjustments required review of the whole pricing structure, not simply the sales tax calculation. The question of market acceptance of the new prices for different categories of goods was the subject of close consideration during that time. The increase in prices occasioned by the sales tax increase was not necessarily in the exact amount of the increase in sales tax. These decisions are necessarily commercial decisions which require close consideration. They cannot be taken instantaneously.

2. A cosmetic manufacturer had on hand on 18 August 1981 brochures prepared for its range of products to be marketed during the coming season. These were purchased at a cost in excess of $25,000. They contain the pre-budget recommended retail prices which are not irrelevant. (The sales tax rise will not be absorbed).

If adverse buyer reaction is to be avoided, the brochures must be overprinted at a cost which compares with the original cost of the brochures. Alternatively, the brochure is to be scrapped and re-printed. Transitional provisions may have avoided such loss.

3. A T.V. rental company finds it's equipment costs increased by approximately $60 per T.V. set and $100 per video cassette recorder. These increases represent an increase of approximately $10 million in the value of equipment to be acquired in the next 5 years. Forward planning in this case was complete for that period. That planning is now meaningless in terms of the increase in sales tax.
In the interim period the company is placed in the position of justifying the increased rentals on the ground of sales tax increases which are not yet law.

4. A company engaged in the blending of oils and marketing of oils and greases is affected by the new definition of aids to manufacture and the changes to items 14, 20B, 78B, 107A, 112, 113D, 113E, 113F, 127 of the First Schedule to the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act. As has been the case with other items to the schedule, these changes are unclear as to their practical effect. Item 127 exempts all oils for use for business or industrial purposes other than those for use in connection with the servicing of road vehicles.

Customers of the company will however be unfamiliar with the new provisions, in many cases they appear to be entitled to exemption, but of course they do not at this stage appreciate the Commissioner's certification requirements. The company is thus placed in the position of charging tax where conditional exemption might properly apply. Customers may resist the sales tax which has not previously been charged in the past and which is not yet law, or demand credit adjustments at future dates. In either case the taxpayer company's administrative effort is unnecessarily increased. Again transitional provisions and exposure to public comment would enable less disruptive introduction of the tax and clarification of provisions which are not incontrovertible.

I instance the above cases as examples of the inequitable incidents of the new provisions should they become law with retroactive effect. The difficulties obviously extend across the broad range of sales tax payers. Not the least of these is the resistance of persons to whom the tax is charged to pay tax at the new rates. Only retrospectivity and absence of transitional provisions can produce that response.
Transitional arrangements are clearly warranted. Exposure to public comment in advance of the bills becoming law would also be advantageous.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Premier of Queensland: Defamation Action-The Senate: Answers to Questions-Alleged Sexual Harassment

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a senator for Queensland, I would be failing in my duty if I did not make reference to a most serious situation which has arisen in Queensland. I refer to the suggestion that the taxpayers of Queensland have to foot the bill because the Premier of that State has lost a defamation action brought against him by a private citizen. Queensland residents are well aware of what occurred, but for those who do not read Queensland newspapers on a regular basis, I will give a brief outline of some of the relevant events. Mr John Sinclair, who was named Australian of the Year on 1 January 1977 by the Australian newspaper, took court action against the Premier of Queensland for defamation. The alleged defamation occurred after Mr Sinclair was named Australian of the Year. Last Friday the Supreme Court in Queensland found in Mr Sinclair's favour and awarded him $500 damages plus costs.

SPEECH.PARA: The $500 is a relatively small amount, but the court's findings were a significant moral victory for Mr Sinclair. A man of immense fortitude, Mr Sinclair was known before this case as a David not unwilling to take on a Goliath. The result of the court case has publicly boosted that image. The Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, did not become liable to pay only that $500 awarded to Mr Sinclair by the court. The costs for which the Premier became liable are believed to be in the order of $30,000. I suspect that $30,000 is a minute amount to the Premier of Queensland, but I also suspect that the more wealth one has the less one is willing to relinquish any of it. That seems to be the case with Mr Bjelke-Petersen.

Queensland residents were astonished when it was hinted that Mr Bjelke-Petersen's costs may be paid by the Queensland Government; in other words, by the Queensland taxpayers. The astonishment of Queenslanders, however, soon increased when it became crystal clear that this was indeed planned; namely, that the taxpayers of Queensland are to be liable for the Premier's defamatory statements. Today the message was quite clear. The Courier-Mail, a newspaper which is published in Brisbane, had a headline emblazoning the front page which stated: 'Taxpayers to pay Joh's legal costs'. The article stated:
Taxpayers will meet the legal costs of the Premier, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, over the John Sinclair defamation case.

There are many serious consequences if indeed the Queensland Government picks up Mr Bjelke-Petersen's costs. Does this mean that the Premier of Queensland can roam at large and make defamatory statements with impunity, aware that if a successful action is taken against him the taxpayers will pick up the tab? Surely the right of members of parliament to make privileged statements within parliament should not extend beyond parliament. This is the obvious implication of what will happen if the Queensland Governments pays the costs of the Premier of Queensland on this occasion. What rights will private citizens have if members of parliament-more precisely, the Premier of Queensland-can make defamatory statements outside the parliament and have no need to be concerned at any action which may be brought against them? Some peculiar things happen in Queensland but this abuse of Executive power must be regarded as one of the most disturbing actions of the Bjelke-Petersen Government.

What can be done about this scandal? The Opposition in the Queensland Parliament can protest until the cows come home, but a government with such a thick hide will not be concerned about the Opposition's protestations. But it should not pass unnoticed that the Queensland Government is a coalition of the National Party-the Premier's party-and the Liberal Party. What are the Liberals doing about this move to plunder the Queensland Treasury? Will they fully support the move and all its consequences or are they just too weak-kneed to stand up to Mr Bjelke-Petersen? I suspect that the latter is the case. If Mr Bjelke-Petersen is intent on using the Queensland purse to pay for his defamatory statements made outside the Parliament, there is absolutely nothing that can be done at this stage. He has a tight rein over his National Party members and his Liberal Party coalition members are simply too weak to stand up to him. Nevertheless, whilst nothing can be done at this stage, this action will be remembered for a long time by the Queensland electorate. A government which plunders the public purse to protect a defamatory Premier will eventually have to present itself to an angered electorate. Despite Queensland's malapportioned electorates or, to use the more widely used term, the gerrymander, this action could be the beginning of the end of the Bjelke-Petersen Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with Senator McLaren in congratulating you, Mr Deputy President, on your appointment to the office you now hold. I do so mainly on behalf of those of us who use the adjournment debate as an effective forum for bringing injustices to light. I hope that when I raise many of these matters you will be honoured to be sitting there listening to me. I have a very complex assignment tonight. Like Senator McLaren, by incorporating documents I will cut considerably the time I take. On the Thursday before Parliament adjourned I spoke very savagely about delays in finalising the allegations of sexual harassment of female carriage cleaners at Sydney metropolitan railway depots. At that time I argued that I had an answer from the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Viner) to the effect that on 17 July action would be taken. The fact that nothing had happened, and we were into August, led me to speak very strongly.

SPEECH.PARA: I know Senator Chaney wants to make a contribution on this matter but, to clear the air, I have first of all a letter that I wrote to Mr Viner after that memorable night, in which I drew a comparison between his own physical courage in hobbling around the house with an apparently badly damaged ankle, my own performance at a time when I had a very heavy bout of influenza and the problems of Commissioner Walker. Apparently when the Press mentioned this matter a number of other Conciliation and Arbitration commissioners were worried about whether I was referring to them because the Press did not name Commissioner Walker. To put the matter into its proper perspective, I ask first of all that my follow-up letter to Mr Viner, in which I complimented him on his physical courage, as well as a letter from Mr Viner to me that is a hard-hitting response-if I give it, I have to take it-be incorporated in Hansard.
Sexual Harassment of Female Carriage Cleaners at Sydney Metropolitan Railway Depots
Earlier this year I submitted a Question on Notice which sought information on the action taken by Commissioner Walker in investigating this matter.

It will be recalled that I had to badger your office to speed up a response from the Commissioner. Since the deadline for the Board of Inquiry report to come back to Commissioner Walker was mid-July, I took the opportunity last night in the Senate to make some well chosen words on the continued procrastination of the Commissioner in finalising this matter [vide attached Senate Hansard extract].

I have never missed a day from the Senate due to illness since I came in during the mid 1960s, whilst you have shown courage in continuing on with your Ministerial duties despite a serious foot injury. It was in the face of our dual performances that I won't accept the phony illness of Commissioner Walker as a factor in the delays associated with this inquiry.

As a life member of the A.R.U., I am determined to pursue this campaign against Commissioner Walker until he delivers. Unless I get a prompt reply from you, I will give him a serve on the adjournment of the Senate each night of the sittings on the week we resume.
James Anthony Mulvihill, Senator for New South Wales

I refer to your letter of 28 August 1981 in which you expressed concern with the action taken by Commissioner Walker regarding the investigation being conducted by a Local Industrial Board established under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act.

I am informed that since the tabling of my reply to your question on notice the Local Industrial Board has met on a number of occasions. As I am informed the Board has forwarded its report to Commissioner Walker and the Commissioner will be holding a private conference on 16 September to consider the report.

While I apologise for the delay in forwarding my reply to your earlier question on notice I am most disturbed at the tenor of the remarks which you made during the adjournment debate on 27 August. They quite unfairly and unjustly reflect not only on the integrity of the Commissioners mentioned but on the Commission as a whole. I would hope that both sides of the Parliament would, when commenting on the Commission and its members, have regard to the heavy responsibility they carry and the difficult and demanding nature of the statutory duty they are required to discharge.
I have asked Senator Chaney to have my views on this matter recorded in the Senate Hansard.
A copy of this letter has been forwarded to the President of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission.
Yours sincerely, R. I. VINER Senator J. A. Mulvihill

TALK.START.PARA: —The second letter states that on 16 September there will be a meeting of the board of reference and the Conciliation Commissioner to consider this matter. My only comment, in a temperate manner, is that this matter started a long time ago. Anyone who knows industrial psychology knows that these things should not be left to fester. It is beyond my comprehension why Commissioner Walker could not have met more quickly to get this matter finalised. I only ask for the same physical and mental standards from the Commissioner as the Minister and I and others in this chamber have demonstrated. I stand by that. If I have to choose between being docile to a conciliation commissioner or to 25,000 members of the Australian Railways Union, New South Wales Branch, there is only one decision I will make. I leave it at that for the time being.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of matters have been raised in the adjournment debate tonight. I wish to respond very briefly, firstly, to Senator McLaren. I am advised that the weekly edition of Hansard for the final week of the session which ended in June is yet to be printed. When that final edition is printed the answers to which the honourable senator referred tonight will appear in it so that, with the incorporation of the answers tonight and their inclusion in Hansard of June, when the final printing is done Senator McLaren's answers will appear in Hansard twice.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether I misheard Senator McLaren, but if I did I apologise. I understood him to be saying that he was very critical of the Wran Government for spending $1m of the taxpayers' money just to get them to vote Labor. If that was the thrust of Senator McLaren's outburst, I congratulate him on his non-partisan approach and I agree with him that it is strange that sometimes taxpayers' money is used for these purposes. If, on the other hand, I misheard him and he was more anxious about investment in bonds and about other investments, whether of the State governments or of the Federal Government, I apologise. A very substantial amount is spent by both State and Federal governments advertising for investment funds. If Senator McLaren peruses the newspapers of those States which are under Labor administrations he will find that of necessity they advertise their semi-government borrowings to attract investment, as indeed we find similar advertisements in non-Labor States and with respect to Commonwealth investments. I believe money that is spent in that way on advertising is a legitimate function of government.

With respect to Senator Mulvihill, I would like to place on the record first an apology. Senator Mulvihill, as he indicated in the Senate on 27 August, did give my office 12 hours notice of the matter he wished to raise. The Honourable Ian Viner did give me advice on the matter Senator Mulvihill wished to raise. In fact I was otherwise engaged but I spoke to Senator Mulvihill later that evening and apologised for not being here for the adjournment debate. That might have prevented some of the misunderstanding which flowed from that adjournment debate. However, Mr Viner has asked me to place on the record in the Senate his concern about the comments which were made about the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. I quote from a letter I received from Mr Viner:
I am advised that since the tabling of the reply-
That is, an earlier reply to Senator Mulvihill-

The Local Industrial Board has met on a number of occasions. As I am presently informed the Board has forwarded its report to Commissioner Walker and the Commissioner will be holding a private conference on 16 September to consider the report.

I am most disturbed at the tenor of the remarks which the Senator has made. They quite unfairly and unjustly reflect not only on the integrity of the Commissioners mentioned but on the Commission as a whole. I would hope that both sides of the Parliament would, when commenting on the Commission and its members, have regard to the heavy responsibility they carry and the difficult and demanding nature of the statutory duty they are required to discharge.

In fairness to the Commission I wanted that put on the public record. I am sorry that my absence from the Senate on 27 August prevented an earlier reply being put on the public record which would, of course, have eased the concern of Minister Viner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I claim to have been misrepresented by the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney). When the Minister reads Hansard tomorrow he will see, perhaps to his consternation, that at no time during my speech tonight did I mention the Wran Labor Government of New South Wales spending $1m of New South Wales taxpayers' money trying to secure re-election. I am certain that Senator Chaney knows that that Government will be re-elected without spending 1c of taxpayers' money.
